"sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.news24.com/news24/world/news/no-place-in-israel-would-be-spared-fears-grow-for-all-out-war-after-hezbollah-threatens-israel-20240620", "title": "'No place' in Israel would be spared: Fears grow for all-out war after Hezbollah threatens Israel | News24", "body": "Hezbollah on Wednesday said none of Israel would be spared in a war, after Israel said it had approved plans for a Lebanon offensive, stoking fears of the Gaza conflict spreading.\n\nHezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah said \"no place\" in Israel would \"be spared our rockets\", in a televised address broadcast amid spiralling tensions across the Israel-Lebanon border.\n\nNasrallah - whose powerful Iran-backed group has exchanged near-daily fire with Israel since its ally Hamas' 7 October attack - also threatened the nearby island nation of Cyprus if it opened its airports or bases to Israel \"to target Lebanon\".\n\nThe Mediterranean island is home to two British military bases including an airbase, but they are in sovereign British territory and not controlled by the Cypriot government.\n\nCypriot President Nikos Christodoulides denied his country's involvement in the war and said it was \"part of the solution\", pointing to its role in a maritime humanitarian corridor to Gaza \"recognised by the entire international community\".\n\nREAD | 'Very dangerous to move goods there': UN highlights lawlessness, panic in delivering Gaza aid\n\nMeanwhile, the war between Israel and Hamas raged in Gaza, with Israeli air strikes and clashes between troops and Palestinian militants.\n\nWitnesses and the civil defence agency in the Hamas-run Gaza Strip reported an Israeli bombardment in western Rafah, where medics said drone strikes and shelling killed at least seven people.\n\nAnd medics at the European hospital in Khan Yunis told AFP 10 bodies were brought to the facility after an Israeli air strike killed a group of people on Salah al-Din road, east of Rafah city, as they waited for aid trucks to arrive.\n\nIslamic Jihad, a Palestinian armed group that has fought alongside Hamas, said its militants were battling troops amid Israeli shelling of western Rafah.\n\nThe war has spilled across the region, drawing in a number of Iran-backed groups saying they are acting in solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza.\n\nFears that Israel might launch a full-blown war in Lebanon have spiked, with the Israeli military on Tuesday announcing that \"operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon were approved and validated\".\n\nOn Wednesday, Israel said its warplanes had struck Hezbollah sites in southern Lebanon overnight, while reporting a drone had infiltrated near the border town of Metula and targeted troops in an attack claimed by Hezbollah.\n\nHezbollah, meanwhile, announced the death of four of its fighters.\n\nLebanon's official National News Agency reported Israeli strikes on several areas in south Lebanon on Wednesday morning, including on the border village of Khiam, where an AFP photographer saw a large cloud of smoke.\n\nHezbollah later said it had fired \"dozens of Katyusha rockets and artillery rounds\" toward a barracks in Kiryat Shmona in northern Israel in retaliation for the attacks.\n\nIsrael said the Hezbollah attack caused no casualties and that its own \"artillery struck the sources of fire\".\n\nThe day before, the Islamist group released a more than nine-minute video showing aerial footage purportedly taken over northern Israel, including what it said were sensitive military, defence and energy facilities and infrastructure in the city and port of Haifa.\n\nSpeaking on a visit to troops on the northern border, Israel's military chief Lieutenant General Herzi Halevi said the video showed \"a capability that we knew about\" and that Israel was \"creating solutions to deal with\" it.\n\nThe Israeli army's announcement that its plans for an offensive in Lebanon had been approved, along with a warning from Foreign Minister Israel Katz of Hezbollah's destruction in a \"total war\", came as US envoy Amos Hochstein visited the region to push for de-escalation.\n\nHochstein returned to Israel on Tuesday evening for more talks with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu after a series of meetings in Lebanon, according to an Israeli official.\n\nFormer Israeli security officials were split on the significance of the approval, with one telling AFP there would be an operation in Lebanon \"within a few weeks\" while another said the government was \"more interested in a ceasefire\".\n\nThe cross-border violence has killed at least 478 people in Lebanon, most of them fighters but also including 93 civilians, according to an AFP tally.\n\nIsraeli authorities say at least 15 soldiers and 11 civilians have been killed in the country's north.\n\nSyrian state media said an Israeli strike on military sites in the country's south killed an army officer on Wednesday. Israel has not commented on the report.\n\nThe Israel-Lebanon escalation comes as more than eight months of war have led to dire humanitarian conditions in Gaza and repeated UN warnings of famine.\n\nUN deputy spokesperson Farhan Haq told reporters that in recent weeks there had been \"an improvement\" in aid reaching northern Gaza \"but a drastic deterioration in the south\".\n\nThe unprecedented 7 October attack by Hamas that triggered the war resulted in the deaths of 1 194 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nThe militants also seized 251 hostages. Of these, 116 remain in Gaza, although the army says 41 are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory offensive has killed at least 37 396 people in Gaza, also mostly civilians, according to the territory's health ministry.\n\nA UN report issued on Wednesday detailed six \"indiscriminate and disproportionate\" Israeli strikes that killed at least 218 people in the first two months of the war.\n\nIn a message on the Muslim holiday of Eid al-Adha, US President Joe Biden called for the implementation of a ceasefire plan he outlined in May.\n\nHochstein said the plan would ultimately lead to \"the end of the conflict in Gaza\", which would in turn quell fighting between Israel and Hezbollah.\n\nBut US, Qatari and Egyptian mediation efforts have stalled for months since a one-week truce in {"uri": "2024-06-395139939", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "20:32:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T20:32:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:24:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/hezbollah-threatens-israel-after-military-says-lebanon-offensive-ready/article_83521488-81f3-5451-85f8-4b9bf25478a5.html", "title": "Hezbollah threatens Israel after military says Lebanon offensive ready", "body": "An Israeli firefighter and a resident take cover as sirens sound to warn of rockets launched from southern Lebanon, amid near-daily cross-border clashes\n\nHezbollah on Wednesday said all of Israel would not be spared in the event of war, after Israel said it had approved a plan for a Lebanon offensive, stoking fears that the Gaza war will spread.\n\nHezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah said \"no place\" in Israel would \"be spared our rockets\", in a televised address broadcast amid spiralling tensions across the Israel-Lebanon border.\n\nNasrallah -- whose powerful Iran-backed group has exchanged near-daily fire with Israel since its ally Hamas's October 7 attack -- also threatened the nearby island nation of Cyprus if it opened its airports or bases to Israel \"to target Lebanon\".\n\nThe Mediterranean island is home to two British military bases including an airbase, but they are in sovereign British territory and are not controlled by the Cypriot government.\n\nMeanwhile, the war between Israel and Hamas raged in Gaza, with Israeli air strikes and clashes between troops and Palestinian militants.\n\nWitnesses and the civil defence agency in the Hamas-run Gaza Strip reported Israeli bombardment in western Rafah, where medics said drone strikes and shelling killed at least seven people.\n\nAnd medics at the European hospital in Khan Yunis told AFP that 10 bodies were brought to the facility after a group of people were killed by an Israeli air strike on Salah al-Din road, east of Rafah city, as they waited for aid trucks to arrive.\n\nThe war has spilled across the region, drawing in a number of Iran-backed groups acting in solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza.\n\n- 'Greater capabilities' -\n\nFears that Israel might launch a full-blown war in Lebanon have spiked, with the Israeli military on Tuesday announcing that \"operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon were approved and validated\".\n\nOn Wednesday, Israel said its warplanes had struck Hezbollah sites in southern Lebanon overnight, while reporting a drone had infiltrated near the border town of Metula and targeted troops in an attack claimed by Hezbollah.\n\nHezbollah, meanwhile, announced the death of four of its fighters.\n\nLebanon's official National News Agency reported Israeli strikes on several areas in south Lebanon on Wednesday morning, including on the border village of Khiam, where an AFP photographer saw a large cloud of smoke.\n\nHezbollah later said it had fired \"dozens of Katyusha rockets and artillery rounds\" towards a barracks in Kiryat Shmona in northern Israel in retaliation for the attacks.\n\nIsrael said the Hezbollah attack did not cause any casualties and that its own \"artillery struck the sources of fire\".\n\nThe day before, the Islamist group released a more than nine-minute video showing aerial footage purportedly taken over northern Israel, including what it said were sensitive military, defence and energy facilities and infrastructure in the city and port of Haifa.\n\nSpeaking on a visit to troops on the northern border, Israel's military chief Lieutenant General Herzi Halevi said the video showed \"a capability that we knew about\" and that Israel was \"creating solutions to deal with\".\n\n\"We of course have infinitely greater capabilities,\" he added.\n\n- 'Total war' -\n\nThe Israeli army's announcement that its plans for an offensive in Lebanon had been approved, along with a warning from Foreign Minister Israel Katz of Hezbollah's destruction in a \"total war\", came as US envoy Amos Hochstein visited the region to push for de-escalation.\n\nHochstein returned to Israel on Tuesday evening for more talks with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu after a series of meetings in Lebanon, according to an Israeli official.\n\nFormer Israeli security officials were split on the significance of the approval, with one telling AFP there would be an operation in Lebanon \"within a few weeks\" while another said the government was \"more interested in a ceasefire\".\n\nThe cross-border violence has killed at least 478 people in Lebanon, most of them fighters but also including 93 civilians, according to an AFP tally.\n\nIsraeli authorities say at least 15 soldiers and 11 civilians have been killed in the country's north.\n\nSyrian state media said an Israeli strike on military sites in the country's south killed an army officer on Wednesday. Israel has not commented on the report.\n\n- 'Drastic deterioration' in aid -\n\nThe Israel-Lebanon escalation comes as more than eight months of war have led to dire humanitarian conditions in Gaza and repeated UN warnings of famine.\n\nUN deputy spokesman Farhan Haq told reporters that in recent weeks, there had been \"an improvement\" in aid reaching northern Gaza \"but a drastic deterioration in the south\".\n\nWhile the humanitarian situation remains dire, fighting in the Gaza Strip continued.\n\nIslamic Jihad, a Palestinian armed group that has fought alongside Hamas, said its militants were battling troops amid Israeli shelling of western Rafah.\n\nThe October 7 attack that triggered the war resulted in the deaths of 1,194 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nThe militants also seized 251 hostages. Of these, 116 remain in Gaza, although the army says 41 are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory offensive has killed at least 37,396 people in Gaza, also mostly civilians, according to the territory's health ministry.\n\nIn a message on the occasion of the Muslim holiday of Eid al-Adha, US President Joe Biden called for the implementation of a ceasefire plan he outlined last month.\n\nHochstein said the plan would ultimately lead to \"the end of the conflict in Gaza\", which would in turn quell fighting between Israel and Hezbollah.\n\nBut US, Qatari and Egyptian mediation efforts have stalled for months since a one-week truce in November.\n\nA UN report issued Wednesday detailed six \"indiscriminate and disproportionate\" Israeli strikes that killed at least 218 people in the first two months of the war.\n\nburs-dcp/jsa\n\nMore from this section\n\nLatinx Festival on L. On Tuesday, the Iran-backed group published what it said was drone footage of sensitive military sites deep in Israeli territory. In a televised address on Wednesday, Hezbollah chief Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah said \"there will be no place safe from our missiles and our drones\" in Israel in the event of a broader war.\n\nThe group also had \"a bank of targets\" that it could target in precision strikes, he said. Israel \"knows that what also awaits it in the Mediterranean is very big,\" Nasrallah added, without elaborating.\n\nThe group first showed it could hit a vessel at sea by striking an Israeli warship in the Mediterranean during their 2006 war. Reports by media and analysts have for years indicated that Hezbollah acquired Russian-made anti-ship Yakhont missiles in Syria, after its forces deployed there more than a decade ago to help President Bashar al-Assad fight the country's civil war.\n\nNasrallah also threatened Cyprus for the first time, saying it had been allowing Israel to use its airports and bases for military exercises. \"The Cypriot government must be warned that opening Cypriot airports and bases for the Israeli enemy to target Lebanon means that the Cypriot government has become part of the war and the resistance (Hezbollah) will deal with it as part of the war,\" Nasrallah said.\n\nCyprus is not known to offer any land or base facilities to the Israeli military, but has in the past allowed Israel to use its vast airspace - its flight information region (FIR) - to occasionally conduct air drills, but never during conflict. Sovereign British military bases have been used for operations in Syria and more recently, Yemen. The Cyprus government has no say in the matter. But I won't say what they are,' he said in a televised address commemorating a top Hezbollah commander killed in an Israeli airstrike in southern Lebanon last week. 'When the decision is made, they will be seen on the front lines.'\n\nHe said that if Israel chose to escalate a war with Lebanon, there would be wider regional consequences.\n\nHe claimed Hezbollah would attack any other country in the region that assisted Israel in the war effort, citing Cyprus, which has hosted Israeli forces for training exercises. He suggested Cyprus might allow Israel to use its bases in event of a wider war.\n\nHezbollah's militant leader (pictured) has boasted of developing 'new weapons' that could be used on the 'front lines' of a potential conflict with Cyprus\n\nThe militant group also hinted at throwing fuel on the fire of conflict between itself and Israel , after publishing chilling footage of its drones scouting targets in the north of its enemy's territory\n\nHezbollah members and supporters of the Iran-backed Lebanese Shiite militia bury Commander Hassan Yehya Naameh on May 20\n\nSmoke billows during Israeli bombardment on the village of Khiam in south Lebanon near the border with Israel on June 19, 2024\n\nIn response, Cypriot President Nikos Christodoulides said his island nation 'is in no way involved' in any military operations in the region. Cyprus is 'part of the solution, not part of the problem' he said, pointing out the Cyprus-Gaza maritime corridor used to deliver aid to the Palestinian territory.\n\nNasrallah's fiery comments came as the monthslong cross-border conflict simmering between Hezbollah and Israel appears to be reaching a boiling point.\n\nThe nearly 10-minute long video published on Tuesday was the clearest indication of a willingness to escalate the conflict.\n\nThe footage allegedly shows reconnaissance drones flying over Haifa, a city deep in Israel.\n\nHaifa is home to the Port of Haifa, one of Israel's three international seaports. The city also plays host to a well-developed military base, which the footage claims would be a target in an upcoming conflict.\n\nThe footage, which was geolocated to the western side of the port, claims to show, among other military targets, buildings belonging to a submarine unit, logistics and support ships, Dvora-class patrol ships and German-made Sa'ar corvette warships.\n\nSmoke rises as a result of an Israeli air strike in the southern Lebanese town of Khiam,\n\nA fire rages resulting from Israeli military shelling that swept over the fields and reached the houses, in the village of Shebaa, close to the southern Lebanese border with Israel\n\nHezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah delivers a speech via a screen at a memorial ceremony for senior Field Commander, Taleb Sami Abdallah\n\nNasrallah said Hezbollah has much more footage - an apparent threat it could reach sites deep in Israel.\n\nIsrael's military chief, Lieutenant General Herzi Halevi, visited Israeli air-defense soldiers near the border with Lebanon on Wednesday, saying Israel was aware of Hezbollah's capabilities demonstrated in the video and has solutions for these threats.\n\n'We of course have infinitely greater capabilities,' he said. 'I think the enemy is only familiar with a few of them and (we) will confront them at the right time.'\n\nHezbollah, an ally of the Palestinian militant group Hamas, has been exchanging strikes with Israel almost daily since the war in Gaza erupted on Oct. 7, with the aim to pull Israeli forces away from the embattled Gaza Strip.\n\nHezbollah's attacks escalated after Israel expanded its offensive into the southern Gaza city of Rafah in May, and spiked further in June after an Israeli strike killed high-ranking Hezbollah commander Taleb Sami Abdullah, the most senior militant killed so far during the Israel-Hamas war.\n\nAlso Tuesday, the Israeli army said it has 'approved and validated' plans for an offensive in Lebanon, although the decision to actually launch such an operation would have to come from the country's political leadership.\n\nThe warnings by both sides followed a visit by Joe Biden's senior adviser Amos Hochstein, who met with officials in Lebanon and Israel in his latest attempt to deescalate tensions.\n\nHochstein told reporters in Beirut on Tuesday that it was a 'very serious situation' and that a diplomatic solution to prevent a larger war was urgent.\n\nIsrael views Hezbollah as its most direct threat, and the two fought a 34-day war in 2006 that ended in a stalemate.\n\nHezbollah's military capabilities have grown significantly since then, and the United States and Israel estimate the group, along with other Lebanese militant factions, has about 150,000 missiles and rockets. He also threatened Cyprus if it allows Israel to use its airports and bases in a full-scale conflict.\n\n\"The enemy knows very well that we have prepared ourselves for the most difficult days, and the enemy knows what it will face,\" Mr. Nasrallah said. \"If war is imposed, the resistance will fight without constraints, rules or limits.\"\n\nPresident Nikos Christodoulides of Cyprus responded to the threat by saying that his country was \"absolutely not involved in any way,\" according to remarks posted on social media.\n\nIn his first public remarks amid the recent flare-up of violence along Lebanon's border with Israel, Mr. Nasrallah said that Hezbollah, which is tightly allied with Iran, did not want a wider conflict but emphasized that the group was ready for war and had so far used only a fraction of its weapons. If needed, Mr. Nasrallah said, Hezbollah could unleash them on \"a bank of targets\" in precision strikes.\n\n\"The enemy knows it must expect us on land, in the air, and at sea,\" he said.\n\nEver since Hezbollah began trading fire with Israeli forces in the wake of the Hamas-led assault on Israel on Oct. 7, over 100 civilians in Israel and Lebanon have been killed, and more than 150,000 have been displaced from their homes. But the cross-border fighting in recent weeks has been among the fiercest yet, raising fears of another front in the war as Israel presses ahead with its offensive in the Gaza Strip.\n\nWestern diplomats have tried to lower the temperature, meeting with Lebanese and Israeli officials to head off a full-fledged war, but on Tuesday the Israeli military said it had approved operational plans for a potential offensive in Lebanon, without specifying when or if the plans would be used. {"uri": "8187358368", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:09:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:09:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T16:08:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://legalinsurrection.com/2024/06/hezbollah-terror-chief-nasrallah-threatens-israel-with-war-without-limits/", "title": "Hezbollah Terror Chief Nasrallah Threatens Israel With War 'Without Limits'", "body": "The head of the Iran-backed Hezbollah terrorist group has threatened Israel with an all-out war. The Lebanon-based Shia-Islamist group will unleash a war with \"no restraint and no rules and no ceilings\" against Israel, Hezbollah terror chief Hassan Nasrallah declared Wednesday.\n\nThere is \"no place in [Israel] that would be spared our rockets and drones,\" Nasrallah, whose terrorist group has been armed with thousands of rockets and missiles by the Iranian regime, boasted.\n\nHezbollah chief's call for an all-out war on Israel is a big blow to President Joe Biden's policy of appeasement toward Hezbollah and its puppet masters in Tehran.\n\nNasrallah's threats come days after the Biden administration told Israel 'not to escalate' tensions with Hezbollah despite the Lebanon-backed terror group intensifying cross-border rocket and drone attacks, causing tens of thousands of Israelis to flee their homes in the north. Hezbollah has stepped up attacks on Israel following the October 7 massacres by Hamas, an allied Iran-sponsored terror group.\n\nNasrallah also threatened the Mediterranean island nation of Cyprus if it supported Israel in case of a military conflict.\n\nThe head of Lebanon's Hezbollah said on Wednesday that nowhere in Israel would be safe if a full-fledged war breaks out between the two foes, and also threatened EU member Cyprus for the first time and other parts of the Mediterranean.\n\nHezbollah has been trading fire with Israel for more than eight months in parallel with the Gaza war. On Tuesday, the Iran-backed group published what it said was drone footage of sensitive military sites deep in Israeli territory.\n\nIn a televised address on Wednesday, Hezbollah chief Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah said \"there will be no place safe from our missiles and our drones\" in Israel in the event of a broader war.\n\nThe group also had \"a bank of targets\" that it could target in precision strikes, he said.\n\nIsrael \"knows that what also awaits it in the Mediterranean is very big ... In the face of a battle of this magnitude, it knows that it must now wait for us on land, in the air, and at sea,\" Nasrallah added.\n\nNasrallah also threatened Cyprus - the EU member state in closest proximity to Lebanon, with which it has cordial relations - accusing it of allowing Israel to use its airports and bases for military exercises.\n\n\"The Cypriot government must be warned that opening Cypriot airports and bases for the Israeli enemy to target Lebanon means that the Cypriot government has become part of the war and the resistance (Hezbollah) will deal with it as part of the war,\" Nasrallah said.\n\nThe Israel Defense Forces (IDF) was mobilizing troops to counter the growing Hezbollah threat along the northern border, IDF Chief of the General Staff, Lt.-Gen. Herzi Halevi assured Wednesday.\n\n\"We are in a state of war for over eight months, and you have defended for over eight months, providing a complex defense,\" the IDF Chief of Staff said. \"This defense gives a great deal of security to civilians and the IDF, but we are not satisfied with that, we have many more soldiers in the IDF who are engaged in an offensive against Hezbollah.\"\n\nIf Hezbollah launched an offensive, it would face advanced military capabilities previously unknown to the terrorist group. \"We of course have infinitely greater capabilities, of which I think the enemy is only familiar with few of them and will confront them at the right time,\" Halevi assured.\n\nAn Israeli airstrike eliminated Hamas's elite terrorist Nukhba commander, who led jihadist fighters into Israel on October 7, the IDF revealed Wednesday. Hamas's Nukhba forces spearheaded the terrorist invasion of October 7, murdering 1200 Israelis and taking 251 as hostages to Gaza.\n\nBacked by intelligence from the IDF and the Shin Bet security agency, an Israeli \"aircraft conducted a precise and targeted strike to eliminate the Hamas terrorist Ahmed Hassan Salame Alsauarka in the area of Beit Hanoun in northern Gaza,\" the Israeli military announced Thursday.\n\nThe slain terrorist \"Ahmed Hassan Salameh a-Swarkeh ... invaded Israeli towns on October 7, and was later behind sniper attacks against Israeli forces in Beit Hanoun [northern Gaza],\" The Times of Israel reported.\n\n\"IDF troops are continuing to operate in the area of the central Gaza Strip,\" the Israeli military disclosed in a press release Thursday. The Israeli \"troops are continuing precise, intelligence-based, operational activity in the Rafah area,\" the IDF statement added. \"Over the past day, the troops eliminated several terrorists in close-quarters encounters. {"uri": "8185962621", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:21:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:21:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:16:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/head-of-lebanons-hezbollah-threatens-israel-and-cyprus/2138883/", "title": "Head of Lebanon's Hezbollah threatens Israel and Cyprus", "body": "In a televised address on Wednesday, Hezbollah chief Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah said \"there will be no place safe from our missiles and our drones\" in Israel in the event of a broader war.\n\nThe group also had \"a bank of targets\" that it could target in precision strikes, he said.\n\nIsrael \"knows that what also awaits it in the Mediterranean is very big ... In the face of a battle of this magnitude, it knows that it must now wait for us on land, in the air, and at sea,\" Nasrallah added.\n\nIsraeli Foreign Minister Israel Katz had warned on Tuesday that a decision on an all-out war with Hezbollah was coming soon and Israel's military said \"operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon were approved and validated\".\n\nNasrallah also threatened Cyprus - the EU member state in closest proximity to Lebanon, with which it has cordial relations - accusing it of allowing Israel to use its airports and bases for military exercises.\n\n\"The Cypriot government must be warned that opening Cypriot airports and bases for the Israeli enemy to target Lebanon means that the Cypriot government has become part of the war and the resistance (Hezbollah) will deal with it as part of the war,\" Nasrallah said.\n\nCypriot President Nikos Christodoulides denied any suggestion Cyprus was taking sides in any conflict.\n\n\"It (Cyprus) is not part of the problem, it is part of the solution. That role is evident, for example, through the humanitarian (aid) corridor which has been acknowledged not only by the Arab world, but from the international community,\" he said, referring to shipments of aid from Cyprus to Gaza.\n\nCyprus is not known to offer any land or base facilities to the Israeli military, but has in the past allowed Israel to use its vast airspace - its flight information region - to occasionally conduct air drills, but never during conflict.\n\nSovereign British military bases on Cyprus have been used by Britain for operations in Syria in the past and more recently, Yemen. The Cyprus government has no say in the matter. There are two British bases in Cyprus, which was a colony until 1960.\n\nNasrallah said his group would fight with \"no rules\" and \"no ceilings\" in the event of a broader war. He was speaking at a memorial event for a commander killed in an Israeli strike last week - the most senior Hezbollah figure to be killed so far in the current conflict with Israel.\n\nHezbollah unleashed its largest volleys of drones and rockets at Israel in retaliation. U.N. officials expressed concern at the escalation, and U.S. envoy Amos Hochstein travelled to Israel and Lebanon to urge both sides not to move into a full-scale conflict.\n\nHezbollah first showed it could hit a vessel at sea by striking an Israeli warship in the Mediterranean during their 2006 war.\n\nReports by media and analysts have for years indicated that Hezbollah acquired Russian-made anti-ship Yakhont missiles in Syria, after its forces deployed there more than a decade ago to help President Bashar al-Assad fight the country's civil war.\n\n(This story has been refiled to fix the spelling of Cyprus in the crosshead)\n\n(Reporting by Laila Bassam and Maya Gebeily; Additional reporting by Michele Kambas in Nicosia; Editing by William Maclean, Angus MacSwan and Alison Williams)", {"uri": "8187170294", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "14:05:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T14:05:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T14:04:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/galleries/article-13551121/Hezbollah-chief-boasts-new-weapons-Cyprus-attack-threat.html", "title": "Hezbollah chief boasts of 'new weapons' after Cyprus attack threat", "body": "Hezbollah's militant leader has boasted of developing 'new weapons' that could be used on the 'front lines' of a potential conflict with Cyprus, drawing more nations into growing tensions in the Middle East. The militant group also hinted at throwing fuel on the fire of conflict between itself and Israel, after publishing chilling footage of its drones scouting targets in the north of its enemy's territory. Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah, the militant group's chief, claimed in a televised speech on Wednesday that he is in command of new weapons and intelligence capabilities that could help it target more critical positions deeper inside Israel in case of an all-out war.\n\n'We now have new weapons. But I won't say what they are,' he said in a televised address commemorating a top Hezbollah commander killed in an Israeli airstrike in southern Lebanon last week. 'When the decision is made, they will be seen on the front lines.' He said that if Israel chose to escalate a war with Lebanon, there would be wider regional consequences. He claimed Hezbollah would attack any other country in the region that assisted Israel in the war effort, citing Cyprus, which has hosted Israeli forces for training exercises. He suggested Cyprus might allow Israel to use its bases in the event of a wider war.\n\nIn response, Cypriot President Nikos Christodoulides said his island nation 'is in no way involved' in any military operations in the region. Cyprus is 'part of the solution, not part of the problem' he said, pointing out the Cyprus-Gaza maritime corridor used to deliver aid to the Palestinian territory. Nasrallah's fiery comments came as the months-long cross-border conflict simmering between Hezbollah and Israel appears to be reaching a boiling point. The nearly 10-minute-long video published on Tuesday was the clearest indication of a willingness to escalate the conflict.\n\nThe footage allegedly shows reconnaissance drones flying over Haifa, a city deep in Israel. Haifa is home to the Port of Haifa, one of Israel's three international seaports. The city also plays host to a well-developed military base, which the footage claims would be a target in an upcoming conflict. The footage, which was geolocated to the western side of the port, claims to show, among other military targets, buildings belonging to a submarine unit, logistics and support ships, Dvora-class patrol ships and German-made Sa'ar corvette warships. Nasrallah said Hezbollah has much more footage - an apparent threat it could reach sites deep in Israel.\n\nIsrael's military chief, Lieutenant General Herzi Halevi, visited Israeli air-defense soldiers near the border with Lebanon on Wednesday, saying Israel was aware of Hezbollah's capabilities demonstrated in the video and has solutions for these threats. 'We of course have infinitely greater capabilities,' he said.\n\n'I think the enemy is only familiar with a few of them and (we) will confront them at the right time.' Hezbollah, an ally of the Palestinian militant group Hamas, has been exchanging strikes with Israel almost daily since the war in Gaza erupted on Oct. 7, with the aim to pull Israeli forces away from the embattled Gaza Strip.\n\nHezbollah's attacks escalated after Israel expanded its offensive into the southern Gaza city of Rafah in May, and spiked further in June after an Israeli strike killed high-ranking Hezbollah commander Taleb Sami Abdullah, the most senior militant killed so far during the Israel-Hamas war. Also Tuesday, the Israeli army said it has 'approved and validated' plans for an offensive in Lebanon, although the decision to actually launch such an operation would have to come from the country's political leadership.\n\nThe warnings by both sides followed a visit by Joe Biden's senior adviser Amos Hochstein, who met with officials in Lebanon and Israel in his latest attempt to deescalate tensions. Hochstein told reporters in Beirut on Tuesday that it was a 'very serious situation' and that a diplomatic solution to prevent a larger war was urgent.\n\nIsrael views Hezbollah as its most direct threat, and the two fought a 34-day war in 2006 that ended in a stalemate. Hezbollah's military capabilities have grown significantly since then, and the United States and Israel estimate the group, along with other Lebanese militant factions, has about 150,000 missiles and rockets. Hezbollah also has been working on precision-guided missiles.\n\nWant more stories like this from the Daily Mail? {"uri": "8186274204", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "03:51:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T03:51:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T03:50:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.dawn.com/news/1840767", "title": "Fighting rages in Gaza's Rafah; tensions with Lebanon soar", "body": "GAZA STRIP: Israeli air strikes and clashes between troops and Palestinian militants rocked Gaza on Wednesday, after Israel's army warned it had readied an offensive against Lebanon's Hezbollah movement on the country's northern front.\n\nWitnesses and the civil defence agency in the Hamas-run Gaza Strip reported Israeli bombardment in western Rafah, where medics said drone strikes and shelling killed at least seven people.\n\nThe Israeli military has announced a daily humanitarian \"pause\" in fighting on a key road in eastern Rafah, but a United Nations spokesman said days later that \"this has yet to translate into more aid reaching people in need\".\n\nMore than eight months of war have led to dire humanitarian conditions in the Palestinian territory and repeated UN warnings of famine.\n\nThe Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt has been shut since Israeli troops seized its Palestinian side in early May, while nearby Kerem Shalom on the Israeli border \"is operating with limited functionality, including because of fighting in the area\", said UN deputy spokesman Farhan Haq.\n\nHe told reporters that in recent weeks, there had been \"an improvement\" in aid reaching northern Gaza \"but a drastic deterioration in the south\".\n\n\"Basic commodities are available in markets in southern and central Gaza.\n\nOffensive against Hezbollah\n\nThe Israeli military, which has traded near-daily cross-border fire with Lebanon's Hezbollah since October, said late Tuesday that \"operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon were approved and validated\".\n\nOn Wednesday the military said its warplanes had struck Hezbollah sites in southern Lebanon overnight, while reporting a drone had infiltrated near the border town of Metula in an attack claimed by Hezbollah targeting troops.\n\nThe Hezbollah also announced the death of four of its fighters.\n\nLebanon's official National News agency reported Israeli strikes on several areas in south Lebanon on Wednesday morning, including on the border village of Khiam. Hezbollah later said it had fired dozens of Katyusha rockets and artillery rounds towards a barracks in Kiryat Shmona in northern Israel in retaliation for the attacks.\n\nIsrael said the Hezbollah attack did not cause any casualties and that its own \"artillery struck the sources of fire\".\n\nHezbollah warning to Israel\n\nHezbollah chief Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah on Wednesday warned Israel there would be a safe place in Israel from Hezbollah attacks if Tel Aviv launches a broader war against it, including targets in the Mediterranean.\n\nIn a televised address on Wednesday, Nasrallah said \"there will be no place safe from our missiles and our drones\" in Israel in the event of a broader war. The group also had \"a bank of targets\" that it could target in precision strikes, he said.\n\nIsrael \"knows that what also awaits it in the Mediterranean is very big...In the face of a battle of this magnitude, it knows that it must now wait for us on land, in the air, and at sea,\" Nasrallah added.\n\nHezbollah has been trading fire with Israel for more than eight months in parallel with the Gaza war. Most of the fatalities have been fighters but they also include more than 80 civilians and non-combatants. On the Israeli side, 16 soldiers and 11 civilians have been killed over the past eight months.\n\nThe level of threats between Israel and Hezbollah intensified following last week\u00b4s killing by Israel of Hezbollah\u00b4s most senior commander since the fighting began. (AP Photo/Bilal Hussein)\n\nCyprus and Lebanon have had close and historic relations for decades and the island became a refuge for thousands of Lebanese who resided on the island during Lebanon\u00b4s 1975-90 civil war. Many Lebanese citizens moved again to Cyprus following the historic economic meltdown in Lebanon that started in late 2019.\n\nIn recent years, Cyprus has enjoyed increasingly tight relations with Israel and the island has hosted joint Israeli-Cypriot military exercises, but has not been involved in any military operations.\n\nNasrallah said his group has information that the Israel\u00b4s "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://timesofmalta.com/article/hezbollah-chief-says-nowhere-israel-spared-case-fullblown-war.1094185", "title": "Hezbollah chief says nowhere in Israel will be spared in case of full-blown war", "body": "Hezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah on Wednesday warned \"no place\" in Israel would be spared in case of a full-blown war and threatened nearby Cyprus if it opened its airports and bases to Israel.\n\n\"The enemy knows well that we have prepared ourselves for the worst... and that no place... will be spared our rockets,\" Nasrallah said in a televised address.\n\nIsrael must expect \"us on land, by sea and by air\", he said.\n\n\"The enemy really fears that the resistance will penetrate Galilee\" in northern Israel, he said, adding that this was possible \"in the context of a war that could be imposed on Lebanon\".\n\nIsrael and Hezbollah, a powerful Lebanese movement allied with Hamas, have traded near-daily cross-border fire since the Palestinian militant group's October 7 attack on Israel which triggered war in the Gaza Strip.\n\nThe exchanges have escalated in recent weeks, and the Israeli military said Tuesday that \"operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon were approved and validated\".\n\nEarlier, Foreign Minister Israel Katz had warned of Hezbollah's destruction in a \"total war\".\n\n\"Opening Cypriot airports and bases to the Israeli enemy to target Lebanon would mean that the Cypriot government is part of the war, and the resistance will deal with it as part of the war,\" Nasrallah threatened.\n\nCyprus has good relations with both Israel and Lebanon, and lies close to the coast of both countries.\n\nBritain has retained sovereign control over two base areas in its former colony Cyprus under the terms of the treaties that granted the island independence in 1960.\n\nNasrallah also warned that his group had only used \"a part of\" its weapons since October.\n\n\"We have obtained new weapons,\" Nasrallah said, without elaborating.\n\n\"We have developed some of our weapons... and we are keeping others for the days that will come,\" he said.\n\n\"Years ago we talked about 100,000 fighters... today, we have greatly exceeded\" that number, Nasrallah said.\n\nThe Israel-Lebanon clashes have killed at least 478 people in Lebanon, most of them fighters but also including 93 civilians, according to an "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/06/20/world/americas-emea/hezbollah-threatens-israel-after-military-says-lebanon-offensive-ready/1952326", "title": "Hezbollah threatens Israel after military says Lebanon offensive ready", "body": "BEIRUT, Lebanon -- Hezbollah on Wednesday said none of Israel would be spared in a war, after Israel said it had approved plans for a Lebanon offensive, stoking fears of the Gaza conflict spreading.\n\nHezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah said \"no place\" in Israel would \"be spared our rockets\", in a televised address broadcast amid spiralling tensions across the Israel-Lebanon border.\n\nNasrallah -- whose powerful Iran-backed group has exchanged near-daily fire with Israel since its ally Hamas's October 7 attack -- also threatened the nearby island nation of Cyprus if it opened its airports or bases to Israel \"to target Lebanon\".\n\nThe Mediterranean island is home to two British military bases including an airbase, but they are in sovereign British territory and not controlled by the Cypriot government.\n\nCypriot President Nikos Christodoulides denied his country's involvement in the war and said it was \"part of the solution\", pointing to its role in a maritime humanitarian corridor to Gaza \"recognised by the entire international community\".\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nMeanwhile, the war between Israel and Hamas raged in Gaza, with Israeli air strikes and clashes between troops and Palestinian militants.\n\nWitnesses and the civil defence agency in the Hamas-run Gaza Strip reported an Israeli bombardment in western Rafah, where medics said drone strikes and shelling killed at least seven people.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAnd medics at the European hospital in Khan Yunis told AFP 10 bodies were brought to the facility after an Israeli air strike killed a group of people on Salah al-Din road, east of Rafah city, as they waited for aid trucks to arrive.\n\nIslamic Jihad, a Palestinian armed group that has fought alongside Hamas, said its militants were battling troops amid Israeli shelling of western Rafah.\n\nThe war has spilled across the region, drawing in a number of Iran-backed groups saying they are acting in solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza.\n\n'Greater capabilities'\n\nAdvertisement\n\nFears that Israel might launch a full-blown war in Lebanon have spiked, with the Israeli military on Tuesday announcing that \"operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon were approved and validated\".\n\nOn Wednesday, Israel said its warplanes had struck Hezbollah sites in southern Lebanon overnight, while reporting a drone had infiltrated near the border town of Metula and targeted troops in an attack claimed by Hezbollah.\n\nHezbollah, meanwhile, announced the death of four of its fighters.\n\nLebanon's official National News Agency reported Israeli strikes on several areas in south Lebanon on Wednesday morning, including on the border village of Khiam, where an AFP photographer saw a large cloud of smoke.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHezbollah later said it had fired \"dozens of Katyusha rockets and artillery rounds\" towards a barracks in Kiryat Shmona in northern Israel in retaliation for the attacks.\n\nIsrael said the Hezbollah attack caused no casualties and that its own \"artillery struck the sources of fire\".\n\nThe day before, the Islamist group released a more than nine-minute video showing aerial footage purportedly taken over northern Israel, including what it said were sensitive military, defence and energy facilities and infrastructure in the city and port of Haifa.\n\nSpeaking on a visit to troops on the northern border, Israel's military chief Lieutenant General Herzi Halevi said the video showed \"a capability that we knew about\" and that Israel was \"creating solutions to deal with\" it.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"We of course have infinitely greater capabilities,\" he added.\n\n'Total war'\n\nThe Israeli army's announcement that its plans for an offensive in Lebanon had been approved, along with a warning from Foreign Minister Israel Katz of Hezbollah's destruction in a \"total war\", came as US envoy Amos Hochstein visited the region to push for de-escalation.\n\nHochstein returned to Israel on Tuesday evening for more talks with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu after a series of meetings in Lebanon, according to an Israeli official.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nFormer Israeli security officials were split on the significance of the approval, with one telling AFP there would be an operation in Lebanon \"within a few weeks\" while another said the government was \"more interested in a ceasefire\".\n\nThe cross-border violence has killed at least 478 people in Lebanon, most of them fighters but also including 93 civilians, according to an AFP tally.\n\nIsraeli authorities say at least 15 soldiers and 11 civilians have been killed in the country's north.\n\nSyrian state media said an Israeli strike on military sites in the country's south killed an army officer on Wednesday. Israel has not commented on the report.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n'Drastic deterioration' in aid\n\nThe Israel-Lebanon escalation comes as more than eight months of war have led to dire humanitarian conditions in Gaza and repeated UN warnings of famine.\n\nUN deputy spokesman Farhan Haq told reporters that in recent weeks there had been \"an improvement\" in aid reaching northern Gaza \"but a drastic deterioration in the south\".\n\nThe unprecedented October 7 attack by Hamas that triggered the war resulted in the deaths of 1,194 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nThe militants also seized 251 hostages. Of these, 116 remain in Gaza, although the army says 41 are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory offensive has killed at least 37,396 people in Gaza, also mostly civilians, according to the territory's health ministry.\n\nA UN report issued on Wednesday detailed six \"indiscriminate and disproportionate\" Israeli strikes that killed at least 218 people in the first two months of the war.\n\nIn a message on the Muslim holiday of Eid al-Adha, US President Joe Biden called for the implementation of a ceasefire plan he outlined last month.\n\nHochstein said the plan would ultimately lead to \"the end of the conflict in Gaza\", which would in turn quell fighting between Israel and Hezbollah.\n\nBut US, Qatari and Egyptian mediation efforts have stalled for months since a one-week truce in Hundreds of thousands of Israelis have been forced out of their homes in northern Israel because of the continued terror attacks from Hezbollah.\n\nThe Israel Defense Forces (IDF) said this week that it had approved plans for an offensive campaign in Lebanon to take out Hezbollah.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE DAILYWIRE+ APP\n\n\"As part of the situational assessment, operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon were approved and validated, and decisions were taken on the continuation of increasing the readiness of troops in the field,\" the statement said.\n\nIsraeli Foreign Minister Israel Katz warned Nasrallah that the IDF will completely destroy Hezbollah if it launches any kind of \"all-out war.\"\n\n\"Nasrallah boasts today about filming the ports of Haifa, operated by international companies from China and India, and threatens to attack them,\" Katz said. \"We are very close to the moment of decision to change the rules against Hezbollah and Lebanon. In an all-out war, Hezbollah will be destroyed and Lebanon will be severely hit. The State of Israel will pay a price on the front and home fronts, but with a strong and united nation, and the full power of the IDF, we will restore security to the residents of the north.\"\n\nJoe Truzman, senior research analyst at the Foundation for the Defense of Democracies, said that Nasrallah's threats against Israel ignored basic realities that Hezbollah would have to deal with.\n\n\"The Hezbollah chief's inflammatory rhetoric, laced with warnings and threats against Israel (including Cyprus), barely acknowledges a crucial aspect: Israel would retaliate with devastating consequences for Hezbollah and Lebanon,\" he said. \"The bitter truth is that Nasrallah's aggressive posturing would ultimately lead to a far greater toll on his side, as Israel would exact a severe price in an all-out war. By hardly recognizing this reality, Nasrallah's words lose their bite.\"\n\n\"While a war between Israel and Lebanon would undoubtedly have devastating consequences for both countries, it is important to acknowledge that Hezbollah's decision to launch an attack on Israel on October 8 was the catalyst for this precarious situation,\" he continued. \"By initiating hostilities, Hezbollah has set in Hezbollah later said it had fired dozens of Katyusha rockets and artillery rounds towards a barracks in Kiryat Shmona in northern Israel in retaliation for the attacks.\n\nIsrael said the Hezbollah attack did not cause any casualties and that its own \"artillery struck the sources of fire\".\n\nHezbollah warning to Israel\n\nHezbollah chief Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah on Wednesday warned Israel there would be a safe place in Israel from Hezbollah attacks if Tel Aviv launches a broader war against it, including targets in the Mediterranean.\n\nIn a televised address on Wednesday, Nasrallah said \"there will be no place safe from our missiles and our drones\" in Israel in the event of a broader war. The group also had \"a bank of targets\" that it could target in precision strikes, he said.\n\nIsrael \"knows that what also awaits it in the Mediterranean is very big.\n\nHezbollah has been trading fire with Israel for more than eight months in parallel with the Gaza war. In an all-out war, Hezbollah will be destroyed and Lebanon will be severely hit.\n\nThe State of Israel will pay a price on the front and home fronts, but with a strong and united nation, and the full power of the IDF, we will restore security to the residents of the north.\n\nNasrallah spoke at a memorial for a Hezbollah commander killed by Israel and threatened to use the group's full force against the Jewish state and even its allies in the region - like Cyprus.\n\n\"Opening Cypriot airports and bases to the Israeli enemy to target Lebanon would mean that the Cypriot government is part of the war, and the resistance will deal with it as part of the war,\" Nasrallah said. {"uri": "8185914452", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "20:27:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T20:27:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T20:26:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/hezbollah-threatens-israel-after-military-says-lebanon-offensive-ready/article_e46ffd4e-0f3d-5d3b-8ea8-2920da02fdc9.html", "title": "Hezbollah threatens Israel after military says Lebanon offensive ready", "body": "An Israeli firefighter and a resident take cover as sirens sound to warn of rockets launched from southern Lebanon, amid near-daily cross-border clashes\n\nHezbollah on Wednesday said all of Israel would not be spared in the event of war, after Israel said it had approved a plan for a Lebanon offensive, stoking fears that the Gaza war will spread.\n\nHezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah said \"no place\" in Israel would \"be spared our rockets\", in a televised address broadcast amid spiralling tensions across the Israel-Lebanon border.\n\nNasrallah -- whose powerful Iran-backed group has exchanged near-daily fire with Israel since its ally Hamas's October 7 attack -- also threatened the nearby island nation of Cyprus if it opened its airports or bases to Israel \"to target Lebanon\".\n\nThe Mediterranean island is home to two British military bases including an airbase, but they are in sovereign British territory and are not controlled by the Cypriot government.\n\nMeanwhile, the war between Israel and Hamas raged in Gaza, with Israeli air strikes and clashes between troops and Palestinian militants.\n\nWitnesses and the civil defence agency in the Hamas-run Gaza Strip reported Israeli bombardment in western Rafah, where medics said drone strikes and shelling killed at least seven people.\n\nAnd medics at the European hospital in Khan Yunis told AFP that 10 bodies were brought to the facility after a group of people were killed by an Israeli air strike on Salah al-Din road, east of Rafah city, as they waited for aid trucks to arrive.\n\nThe war has spilled across the region, drawing in a number of Iran-backed groups acting in solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza.\n\n- 'Greater capabilities' -\n\nFears that Israel might launch a full-blown war in Lebanon have spiked, with the Israeli military on Tuesday announcing that \"operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon were approved and validated\".\n\nOn Wednesday, Israel said its warplanes had struck Hezbollah sites in southern Lebanon overnight, while reporting a drone had infiltrated near the border town of Metula and targeted troops in an attack claimed by Hezbollah.\n\nHezbollah, meanwhile, announced the death of four of its fighters.\n\nLebanon's official National News Agency reported Israeli strikes on several areas in south Lebanon on Wednesday morning, including on the border village of Khiam, where an AFP photographer saw a large cloud of smoke.\n\nHezbollah later said it had fired \"dozens of Katyusha rockets and artillery rounds\" towards a barracks in Kiryat Shmona in northern Israel in retaliation for the attacks.\n\nIsrael said the Hezbollah attack did not cause any casualties and that its own \"artillery struck the sources of fire\".\n\nThe day before, the Islamist group released a more than nine-minute video showing aerial footage purportedly taken over northern Israel, including what it said were sensitive military, defence and energy facilities and infrastructure in the city and port of Haifa.\n\nSpeaking on a visit to troops on the northern border, Israel's military chief Lieutenant General Herzi Halevi said the video showed \"a capability that we knew about\" and that Israel was \"creating solutions to deal with\".\n\n\"We of course have infinitely greater capabilities,\" he added.\n\n- 'Total war' - More from this section 'People have worked so hard.' Woman who helped make Juneteenth a national holiday visits New Jersey Germany: Travel Chaos Erupts After England-Serbia Euro 2024 Game In Gelsenkirchen 2 New Jersey power broker George Norcross charged with racketeering in waterfront redevelopment case\n\nThe Israeli army's announcement that its plans for an offensive in Lebanon had been approved, along with a warning from Foreign Minister Israel Katz of Hezbollah's destruction in a \"total war\", came as US envoy Amos Hochstein visited the region to push for de-escalation.\n\nHochstein returned to Israel on Tuesday evening for more talks with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu after a series of meetings in Lebanon, according to an Israeli official.\n\nFormer Israeli security officials were split on the significance of the approval, with one telling AFP there would be an operation in Lebanon \"within a few weeks\" while another said the government was \"more interested in a ceasefire\".\n\nThe cross-border violence has killed at least 478 people in Lebanon, most of them fighters but also including 93 civilians, according to an AFP tally.\n\nIsraeli authorities say at least 15 soldiers and 11 civilians have been killed in the country's north.\n\nSyrian state media said an Israeli strike on military sites in the country's south killed an army officer on Wednesday. Israel has not commented on the report.\n\n- 'Drastic deterioration' in aid -\n\nThe Israel-Lebanon escalation comes as more than eight months of war have led to dire humanitarian conditions in Gaza and repeated UN warnings of famine.\n\nUN deputy spokesman Farhan Haq told reporters that in recent weeks, there had been \"an improvement\" in aid reaching northern Gaza \"but a drastic deterioration in the south\".\n\nWhile the humanitarian situation remains dire, fighting in the Gaza Strip continued.\n\nIslamic Jihad, a Palestinian armed group that has fought alongside Hamas, said its militants were battling troops amid Israeli shelling of western Rafah.\n\nThe October 7 attack that triggered the war resulted in the deaths of 1,194 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nThe militants also seized 251 hostages. Of these, 116 remain in Gaza, although the army says 41 are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory offensive has killed at least 37,396 people in Gaza, also mostly civilians, according to the territory's health ministry.\n\nIn a message on the occasion of the Muslim holiday of Eid al-Adha, US President Joe Biden called for the implementation of a ceasefire plan he outlined last month.\n\nHochstein said the plan would ultimately lead to \"the end of the conflict in Gaza\", which would in turn quell fighting between Israel and Hezbollah.\n\nBut US, Qatari and Egyptian mediation efforts have stalled for months since a one-week truce in November.\n\nA UN report issued Wednesday detailed six \"indiscriminate and disproportionate\" Israeli strikes that killed at least 218 people in the first two months of the war.\n\nburs-dcp/jsa", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8185676417", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:49:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:49:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:48:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-head-of-lebanons-hezbollah-threatens-israel-cyprus-in-televised/", "title": "Head of Lebanon's Hezbollah threatens Israel, Cyprus in televised address", "body": "The head of Lebanon's Hezbollah said on Wednesday that nowhere in Israel would be safe if a full-fledged war breaks out between the two foes, and he also threatened Cyprus and other parts of the Mediterannean.\n\nHezbollah has been trading fire with Israel for more than eight months in parallel with the Gaza War. On Tuesday, the Iran-backed group published what it said was drone footage of sensitive military sites deep in Israeli territory.\n\nIn a televised address on Wednesday, Hezbollah chief Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah said \"there will be no place safe from our missiles and our drones\" in Israel in the event of a broader war.\n\nThe group also had \"a bank of targets\" that it could target in precision strikes, he said.\n\nIsrael \"knows that what also awaits it in the Mediterranean is very big,\" Nasrallah added, without elaborating.\n\nThe group first showed it could hit a vessel at sea by striking an Israeli warship in the Mediterranean during their 2006 war.\n\nReports by media and analysts have for years indicated that Hezbollah acquired Russian-made anti-ship Yakhont missiles in Syria, after its forces deployed there more than a decade ago to help President Bashar al-Assad fight the country's civil war.\n\nNasrallah also threatened Cyprus for the first time, saying it had been allowing Israel to use its airports and bases for military exercises.\n\n\"The Cypriot government must be warned that opening Cypriot airports and bases for the Israeli enemy to target Lebanon means that the Cypriot government has become part of the war and the resistance (Hezbollah) will deal with it as part of the war,\" Nasrallah said.\n\nCyprus is not known to offer any land or base facilities to the Israeli military, but has in the past allowed Israel to use its vast airspace - its flight information region (FIR) - to occasionally conduct air drills, but never during conflict.\n\nSovereign British military bases have been used for operations in Syria and more recently, Yemen. The Cyprus government has no say in the matter. On Tuesday, the group published what it said was drone footage of sensitive military sites deep in Israeli territory.\n\nIn a televised address on Wednesday, Hezbollah chief Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah said \"there will be no place safe from our missiles and our drones\" in Israel in the event of a broader war.\n\nThe group also had \"a bank of targets\" that it could target in precision strikes, he said.\n\nIsrael \"knows that what also awaits it in the Mediterranean is very big...In the face of a battle of this magnitude, it knows that it must now wait for us on land, in the air, and at sea,\" Nasrallah added.\n\nThe group first showed it could hit a vessel at sea by striking an Israeli warship in the Mediterranean during their 2006 war.\n\nReports by media and analysts have for years indicated that Hezbollah acquired Russian-made anti-ship Yakhont missiles in Syria, after its forces deployed there more than a decade ago to help President Bashar al-Assad fight the country's civil war.\n\nNasrallah also threatened Cyprus for the first time, accusing it of allowing Israel to use its airports and bases for military exercises.\n\n\"The Cypriot government must be warned that opening Cypriot airports and bases for the Israeli enemy to target Lebanon means that the Cypriot government has become part of the war and the resistance (Hezbollah) will deal with it as part of the war,\" Nasrallah said.\n\nThere was no immediate comment from authorities in Cyprus. {"uri": "8186460183", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "06:36:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T06:36:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T06:35:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://bnn-news.com/hezbollah-threatens-cyprus-with-war-if-it-helps-israel-258201", "title": "Hezbollah threatens Cyprus with war if it helps Israel - Baltic News Network", "body": "Lebanese Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah on Wednesday, the 19th of June, threatened European Union member Cyprus with war if it allowed Israel to use its territory for military operations against Hezbollah, saying in a televised address that such actions would be considered an act of war and warning that no one in Israel would be safe if a fully-fledged war broke out between the two enemies, report Politico and Reuters.\n\n\"Opening Cypriot airfields and bases for Israel to attack Lebanon would mean that the Cypriot government is engaged in a war,\" Nasrallah said.\n\nHe added that Hezbollah would fight \"without rules\" and \"without ceilings\" if a wider regional conflict erupted.\n\nSince the Hamas attack on Israel on the 7th of October, Iranian-backed Hezbollah fighters have repeatedly attacked Israel with rockets and drones, with Israel responding with air strikes killing hundreds of Hezbollah fighters, including one of their top commanders.\n\nIsraeli military spokesman Daniel Hagari warned on Monday that the region was on the brink of \"a wider escalation that could have devastating consequences\".\n\nIsraeli Foreign Minister Israel Katz said on Tuesday that a decision on a all-out war with Hezbollah would be taken soon, while the Israeli military said that \"operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon have been approved\".\n\nCyprus, located about 250 kilometres from Lebanon, has stepped up its defence cooperation with Israel through joint military exercises and arms procurement contracts. Cyprus is not a member of NATO.\n\n\"Cyprus is not involved in military conflicts and sees itself as part of the solution, not the problem,\"\n\nCypriot President Nikos Christodoulides said on Wednesday in response to the threat.\n\n\"Our humanitarian corridor demonstrates our commitment to peace and stability,\" he told reporters at the graduation ceremony of the University of Cyprus, stressing that Cyprus is a humanitarian facilitator which, he said, \"is recognised all over the world and especially in the Arab world\".\n\nAsked whether Cyprus had contacted Hezbollah or the Lebanese government, he confirmed that Cyprus has open diplomatic channels with both Lebanon and Iran. The President reiterated that \"Cyprus is not participating in the military engagements\" and that while \"such statements are not pleasant, they do not reflect reality\".\n\nCyprus has not, as far as is known, offered land or bases to the Israeli military, but in the past it has allowed Israel to use its extensive airspace for occasional air exercises, but never during a conflict.", "source": ( Image Source :X/@TheocharousH )\n\nHezbollah chief Hasan Nasrallah has issued an all-out warning to Israel that no place will be spared in case of a full-blown war against the Lebanese armed group. He also threatened Cyprus against opening its airports to Israel.\n\n\"The enemy knows well that we have prepared ourselves for the worst... and that no place... will be spared our rockets,\" said the group chief in a televised address, reported AFP.\n\nIsrael must expect \"us on land, by sea and by air\", he said.\n\nALSO READ: Indian Farm Worker Dies In Italy's Latina After Being Dumped On a war last in 2006, have escalated recently and the Israeli military said on Tuesday that \"operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon were approved and validated\".\n\nEarlier, Foreign Minister {"uri": "8187421769", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:58:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:58:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T16:53:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.breitbart.com/middle-east/2024/06/20/hezbollah-chief-says-he-has-100000-terrorists-ready-to-attack-israel-threatens-cyprus/", "title": "Hezbollah Chief Claims 100,000 Terrorists Ready to Attack Israel, Threatens Cyprus", "body": "The head of the Shiite Lebanese terrorist organization Hezbollah, Hassan Nasrallah, threatened to expand his war against Israel in a speech on Wednesday, boasting that he allegedly has 100,000 terrorists at his disposal and suggesting war with Cyprus may also be imminent.\n\nHezbollah, one of many Iranian proxy terrorist organizations, has long maintained ties with the Sunni jihadist group Hamas. The group has expanded its attacks on Israel since October 7, when Hamas terrorists launched an unprecedented invasion of Israel that resulted in an estimated 1,200 deaths, the abduction of about 250 people, and widespread torture, rape, and other atrocities.\n\nHezbollah has focused on attacking northern Israel, near the border with Lebanon, firing hundreds of rockets, missiles and drones into Israel. Hezbollah has also started widespread fires, forcing Israelis to evacuate.\n\nNasrallah delivered his address on Wednesday at a funeral event for Hezbollah terrorists killed in an Israeli counter-operation, emphasizing claims that Israel is lying about its progress in its war on genocidal jihadists and that Hezbollah, despite its documented losses, is putting on an \"effective\" struggle against the country.\n\n\ud83d\udea8\ud83d\udea8\ud83d\udea8 https://t.co/FhqElE41RN\n\n-- Breitbart News (@BreitbartNews) March 18, 2024\n\n\"The resistance's manpower is unprecedented. We have recruited over 100,000 fighters,\" Nasrallah reportedly claimed, according to the Iranian state propaganda outlet PressTV. \"The enemy knows well that we have prepared ourselves for the worst... and that no place... will be spared our rockets.\"\n\n\"Threatening us with war on Lebanon does not scare us, we have prepared ourselves for the most difficult of days and the enemy knows well what awaits it,\" Nasrallah said.\n\nHezbollah has increased its attack on Israel in June, launching hundreds of rockets during the Jewish holiday of Shavuot (Pentecost) and requiring the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) to place tens of thousands of soldiers on the Lebanese border. This week, the IDF announced that it had approved a plan \"for an offensive in Lebanon\" if necessary in response to continuing Hezbollah attacks.\n\nOn Tuesday, Hezbollah published menacing footage of northern Israel apparently taken by its drones, meant to signal that the terrorists had successfully flown reconnaissance aircraft over major population centers such as Haifa. Nasrallah mentioned the footage in his comments on Wednesday, claiming it was part of \"long hours of footage of Haifa, what's around it, what's before it, what's beyond it and what's even further.\"\n\nElsewhere in the remarks, according to PressTV, Nasrallah praised fellow terrorists organizations, claiming the attacks by the Iran-backed Houthis of Yemen against commercial shipping were successful.\n\n\"The United States and Britain have failed to stop Yemeni attacks. The Zionist enemy, unable to engage in other fronts, relies on US and UK support to confront Yemeni forces,\" he was quoted as saying.\n\nNasrallah also reportedly \"went on to highlight the spiritual gift of martyrdom.\" Rather than respond to the losses by focusing on the one Hezbollah front with Israel on the Lebanese border, Nasrallah threatened to expand the war to the Mediterranean Sea, explicitly threatening the nation of Cyprus.\n\n\"The enemy knows that what also awaits it in the Mediterranean Sea is very huge, seeing as all its coasts and ships will be targeted,\" Nasrallah was quoted as saying.\n\nNasrallah threatened the Cypriot government in response to its friendly relationship with the United States and growing ties to Israel.\n\n\"Opening Cypriot airports and bases to the Israeli enemy to target Lebanon would mean that the Cypriot government is part of the war,\" Nasrallah said, \"and the resistance will deal with it as part of the war.\"\n\nThe regional news outlet Middle East Eye noted, citing experts, that the threat was unprecedented against the Mediterranean nation and appeared to be in response to Cypriot Foreign Minister Constantinos Kombos meeting with American Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Monday. In a message posted to his social media account, Blinken framed the meeting as a discussion on helping \"get essential aid to Gaza,\" the Hamas-controlled territory where most of Israel's operations against the jihadists are currently ongoing.\n\nMiddle East Eye noted that Cyprus has expanded \"energy cooperation\" with Israel and welcomed \"an influx of Israeli real estate investment in recent years, ironically, along with renewed interest from Lebanese investors.\"\n\nThe Times of Israel noted in its reporting on Nasrallah's speech that Cyprus is also home to two British bases, helping the U.K. conduct military operations in the region, but \"is not known to offer any land or base facilities to the Israeli military.\"\n\nThe president of Cyprus, Nikos Christodoulides, insisted in response to Nasrallah that his country is \"part of the solution, not part of the problem\" and that Cyprus is \"in no way involved\" in military operations.", "source": {"uri": "breitbart.com", Others, including United States Secretary of State Antony Blinken, have pointed to the difficulty of destroying the Islamist group.\n\nGRAVE THREAT This video image grab from Hezbollah's al-Manar TV on June 19, 2024, shows Hezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah delivering a televised address from an undisclosed location in Lebanon. is home to two British bases, including an air base, but they are in sovereign British territory and not controlled by the Cypriot government.\n\nCypriot President Nikos Christodoulides denied his killed\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe Gaza war was sparked by the October 7 attacks, which resulted in the deaths of 1,194 people, mostly civilians, an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures
