{"uri": "8186385299", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "05:36:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T05:36:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T05:35:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "http://theconversation.com/does-israel-really-want-to-open-a-two-front-war-by-attacking-hezbollah-in-lebanon-232900", "title": "Does Israel really want to open a two-front war by attacking Hezbollah in Lebanon?", "body": "Australian National University provides funding as a member of The Conversation AU.\n\nAmong the many sayings attributed to Winston Churchill is, \"Those who fail to learn from history are doomed to repeat it.\"\n\nThis sentiment seems appropriate as Israel potentially appears ready to embark on a war against the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah in southern Lebanon.\n\nIsraeli Foreign Minister Israel Katz said this week a decision on an all-out war against Hezbollah was \"coming soon\" and that senior commanders of the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) had signed off on a plan for the operation.\n\nThis threat comes despite the fact Israel's war against Hamas in Gaza is far from over. Israel has still not achieved the two primary objectives Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu put forth at the start of the conflict:\n\nthe destruction of Hamas as a military and governing entity in Gaza the freeing of the remaining Israeli hostages held by Hamas (about 80 believed to still be alive, along with the remains of about 40 believed to be dead).\n\nWhy Hezbollah is attacking Israel now\n\nIsrael has cogent reasons for wanting to eliminate the threat from Hezbollah. Hezbollah has been launching Iranian-supplied missiles, rockets and drones across the border into northern Israel since the Gaza war began on October 8. Its stated purpose is to support Hamas by distracting the IDF from its Gaza operation.\n\nHezbollah's attacks have been relatively circumscribed - confined so far to northern Israel. But they have led to the displacement of some 60,000 residents from the border area. These people are understandably fed up and demanding Netanyahu's government takes action to force Hezbollah to withdraw from the border.\n\nThis anger has been augmented this week by Hezbollah publicising video footage of military and civilian sites in the northern Israeli city of Haifa, which had been taken by a low-flying surveillance drone.\n\nThe implication: Hezbollah was scoping the region for new targets. Haifa, a city of nearly 300,000, has not yet been subject to Hezbollah attacks.\n\nThe most far-right members of Netanyahu's cabinet, Bezalel Smotrich and Itamar Ben Gvir, have openly called for Israel to invade southern Lebanon. Even without this pressure, Netanyahu has ample reason to want to neutralise the Hezbollah threat because residents of northern Israel are strong supporters of his Likud party.\n\nUS and Iranian interests in a broader conflict\n\nThe United States is obviously concerned about the risk Israel will open a second front in its conflicts. As such, President Joe Biden has sent an envoy, Amos Hochstein, to Israel and Lebanon to try to reduce tensions on both sides.\n\nIn Lebanon, he can't publicly deal directly with the Hezbollah leader, Hassan Nasrallah, because the group is on the US list of global terrorist organisations. Instead, he met the long-serving speaker of the Lebanese parliament, Nabih Berri, who as a fellow Shia is able to talk with Nasrallah.\n\nBut Hezbollah answers to Iran - its main backer in the region. And it's doubtful if any Lebanese leader can persuade it to desist from action approved by Iran.\n\nIran's interests in the potential for an Israel-Hezbollah war at this time are mixed. It would obviously be glad to see Israel under military pressure on two fronts. But Iranian leaders see Hezbollah as insurance against an Israeli attack on its nuclear facilities.\n\nHezbollah has an estimated 150,000 missiles and rockets, including some that could reach deep into Israel. So far, Iran seems to want Hezbollah to hold back from a major escalation with Israel, which could deplete most of that arsenal.\n\nThat said, although Israel's Iron Dome defensive shield has been remarkably successful in neutralising the rocket threat from Gaza, it might not be as effective against a large-scale barrage of more sophisticated missiles.\n\nIsrael needed help from the US, Britain, France and Jordan in countering a direct attack from Iran in April that involved some 150 missiles and 170 drones.\n\nLessons from previous Israeli interventions in Lebanon\n\nThe other factor - especially for wiser heads mindful of history - is the country's previous interventions in Lebanon have been far from cost-free.\n\nIsrael's problems with Lebanon started when the late King Hussein of Jordan forced the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO), then led by Yasser Arafat, to relocate to Lebanon in 1970. He did that because the PLO had been using Jordan as a base for operations against Israel after the 1967 war, provoking Israeli retaliation.\n\nFrom the early 1970s, the PLO formed a state within a state in Lebanon. It largely acted independently from the perennially weak Lebanese government, which was divided on sectarian grounds, and in 1975, collapsed into a prolonged civil war.\n\nThe PLO used southern Lebanon to launch attacks against Israel, leading Israel to launch a limited invasion of its northern neighbour in 1978, driving Palestinian militia groups north of the Litani River.\n\nThat invasion was only partially successful. Militants soon moved back towards the border and renewed their attacks on northern Israel. In 1982, then-Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin decided to remove the PLO entirely from Lebanon, launching a major invasion of Lebanon all the way to Beirut. This eventually forced the PLO leadership and the bulk of its fighters to relocate to Tunisia.\n\nDespite this success, the two Israeli invasions had the unintended consequence of radicalising the until-then quiescent Shia population of southern Lebanon.\n\nThat enabled Iran, in its early post-revolutionary phase under Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, to work with Shia clerics in Lebanon to establish Hezbollah (Party of God in Arabic), which became a greater threat to Israel than the PLO had ever been.\n\nBolstered by Iranian support, Hezbollah has become stronger over the years, becoming a force in Lebanese politics and regularly firing missiles into Israel.\n\nIn 2006, Hezbollah was able to block an IDF advance into southern Lebanon aimed at rescuing two Israeli soldiers Hezbollah had captured. The outcome was essentially a draw, and the two soldiers remained in captivity until their bodies were exchanged for Lebanese prisoners in 2008.\n\nMany Arab observers at the time judged that by surviving an asymmetrical conflict, Hezbollah had emerged with a political and military victory.\n\nFor a while during and after that conflict, Nasrallah was one of the most popular regional leaders, despite the fact he was loathed by rulers of conservative Sunni Arab states such as Saudi Arabia.\n\nWill history repeat itself?\n\nThis is the background to discussions in Israel about launching a war against Hezbollah. And it demonstrates how the quote from Churchill is relevant.\n\nMost military experts would caution against choosing to fight a war on two fronts. Former US President George W. Bush decided to invade Iraq in 2003 when the war in Afghanistan had not concluded. The outcome was hugely costly for the US military and disastrous for both countries.\n\nThe 19th century American writer Mark Twain is reported to have said that history does not repeat itself, but it often rhymes. {"uri": "8187322344", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "15:43:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T15:43:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:42:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/news/world/2024/0620/1455815-middle-east/", "title": "Israel-Hezbollah tensions drive fears of growing Gaza war", "body": "Fears of a regional war rose after Lebanon's powerful Hezbollah movement said none of Israel would be spared in a full-blown conflict, and Israel said it had approved plans for a Lebanon offensive.\n\nIn the latest border unrest, Hezbollah said it fired dozens of rockets into northern Israel in retaliation for a deadly air strike in south Lebanon that Israel said killed a Hezbollah operative.\n\nExperts are divided on the prospect of wider war, almost nine months into Israel's vow to eradicate Hamas, the Palestinian militant group in Gaza.\n\nIsrael's top military spokesman said Hamas, as an ideology, cannot be eliminated. Others, including US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, have also pointed to the difficulty of destroying the Islamist group.\n\nHezbollah and Israeli forces have exchanged near-daily fire since Hamas's 7 October attack on southern Israel triggered the Gaza war, and aggression has lately escalated along with the strikes.\n\nIn a televised address, the secretary-general of Hezbollah Hassan Nasrallah said \"no place\" in Israel would \"be spared our rockets\" if war began.\n\nThe chief of the Iran-backed group also threatened the nearby island nation of Cyprus if it opened its airports or bases to Israel \"to target Lebanon\".\n\nEuropean Union member Cyprus is home to two British bases, including an airbase, but they are in sovereign British territory and not controlled by the Cypriot government.\n\nThe Cypriot government spokesman today dismissed as \"totally groundless\" any suggestion of possible involvement in a conflict related to Lebanon.\n\n\"Cyprus is not involved, nor will it become involved, in any military conflicts,\" Konstantinos Letymbiotis told state radio.\n\nWarplanes from the British airbase in Cyprus have, along with US forces, carried out reprisal strikes against Yemen's Iran-backed Houthi rebels who have for months been attacking shipping in adjacent waterways.\n\n'Urgent' de-escalation\n\nThe US military yesterday said its forces destroyed two Houthi sites in Yemen.\n\nThe Houthis and Hezbollah both say they are acting in response to Israel's actions in Gaza.\n\nOn Tuesday, Israel's military announced that \"operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon were approved and validated\".\n\nThe same day, Hezbollah published a video showing drone footage purportedly taken by the movement over northern Israel, including parts of Haifa's city and port.\n\nUS envoy Amos Hochstein has called for \"urgent\" de-escalation.\n\nThe cross-border violence has killed at least 479 people in Lebanon, most of them fighters but also 93 civilians, according to an AFP tally.\n\nIsraeli authorities say at least 15 soldiers and 11 civilians have been killed in the country's north.\n\nWeary residents of Beirut on Thursday downplayed the chances of war in Lebanon, which a political deadlock has left essentially leaderless while a five-year economic meltdown continues.\n\nIn Israel, some citizens called for action against Hezbollah, and Noam Galili, 29, said: \"I know what it is like to live close to Lebanon, but it never felt as dangerous as it does now.\"\n\nPressures\n\nThe violence has already displaced tens of thousands of people, mostly in Lebanon but also in northern Israel.\n\nIn southern Gaza, a United Nations mission found hundreds of thousands of displaced people \"suffer from poor access to shelter, health, food, water and sanitation,\" a UN report said.\n\nIn central Gaza, residents said they had turned to cooking oil to power their cars.\n\nUS President Joe Biden has called for the implementation of a ceasefire plan he outlined last month.\n\nAmos Hochstein and Washington's top diplomat, Antony Blinken, say a deal to curb fighting in Gaza would by extension help resolve the Hezbollah-Israel violence.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's far-right coalition partners strongly oppose a Gaza ceasefire.\n\nHe is also facing regular street protests by tens of thousands demanding a deal to free the hostages, and accusing him of prolonging the war.\n\nThe Israeli military spokesman, Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari, told Israel's Channel 13: \"To say that we are going to make Hamas disappear is to throw sand in people's eyes. If we don't provide an alternative, in the end, we will have Hamas.\"\n\nHe said, \"Hamas is an ideology. We cannot eliminate an ideology.\"\n\nMr Blinken last month said Washington had not seen an Israeli post-war plan and \"the trajectory Israel is on\" would still leave thousands of Hamas fighters.", {"uri": "8186364868", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "05:19:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T05:19:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T05:17:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.miragenews.com/israel-to-initiate-two-front-war-by-targeting-1259812/", "title": "Israel to Initiate Two-Front War by Targeting Hezbollah?", "body": "Among the many sayings attributed to Winston Churchill is, \"Those who fail to learn from history are doomed to repeat it.\"\n\nAuthor\n\nIan Parmeter\n\nResearch Scholar, Centre for Arab and Islamic Studies, Australian National University\n\nThis sentiment seems appropriate as Israel potentially appears ready to embark on a war against the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah in southern Lebanon.\n\nIsraeli Foreign Minister Israel Katz said this week a decision on an all-out war against Hezbollah was \"coming soon\" and that senior commanders of the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) had signed off on a plan for the operation.\n\nThis threat comes despite the fact Israel's war against Hamas in Gaza is far from over. Israel has still not achieved the two primary objectives Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu put forth at the start of the conflict:\n\nthe destruction of Hamas as a military and governing entity in Gazathe freeing of the remaining Israeli hostages held by Hamas (about 80 believed to still be alive, along with the remains of about 40 believed to be dead). Why Hezbollah is attacking Israel now\n\nIsrael has cogent reasons for wanting to eliminate the threat from Hezbollah. Hezbollah has been launching Iranian-supplied missiles, rockets and drones across the border into northern Israel since the Gaza war began on October 8. Its stated purpose is to support Hamas by distracting the IDF from its Gaza operation.\n\nHezbollah's attacks have been relatively circumscribed - confined so far to northern Israel. But they have led to the displacement of some 60,000 residents from the border area. These people are understandably fed up and demanding Netanyahu's government takes action to force Hezbollah to withdraw from the border.\n\nThis anger has been augmented this week by Hezbollah publicising video footage of military and civilian sites in the northern Israeli city of Haifa, which had been taken by a low-flying surveillance drone.\n\nThe implication: Hezbollah was scoping the region for new targets. Haifa, a city of nearly 300,000, has not yet been subject to Hezbollah attacks.\n\nThe most far-right members of Netanyahu's cabinet, Bezalel Smotrich and Itamar Ben Gvir, have openly called for Israel to invade southern Lebanon. Even without this pressure, Netanyahu has ample reason to want to neutralise the Hezbollah threat because residents of northern Israel are strong supporters of his Likud party.\n\nUS and Iranian interests in a broader conflict\n\nThe United States is obviously concerned about the risk Israel will open a second front in its conflicts. As such, President Joe Biden has sent an envoy, Amos Hochstein, to Israel and Lebanon to try to reduce tensions on both sides.\n\nIn Lebanon, he can't publicly deal directly with the Hezbollah leader, Hassan Nasrallah, because the group is on the US list of global terrorist organisations. Instead, he met the long-serving speaker of the Lebanese parliament, Nabih Berri, who as a fellow Shia is able to talk with Nasrallah.\n\nBut Hezbollah answers to Iran - its main backer in the region. And it's doubtful if any Lebanese leader can persuade it to desist from action approved by Iran.\n\nIran's interests in the potential for an Israel-Hezbollah war at this time are mixed. It would obviously be glad to see Israel under military pressure on two fronts. But Iranian leaders see Hezbollah as insurance against an Israeli attack on its nuclear facilities.\n\nHezbollah has an estimated 150,000 missiles and rockets, including some that could reach deep into Israel. So far, Iran seems to want Hezbollah to hold back from a major escalation with Israel, which could deplete most of that arsenal.\n\nThat said, although Israel's Iron Dome defensive shield has been remarkably successful in neutralising the rocket threat from Gaza, it might not be as effective against a large-scale barrage of more sophisticated missiles.\n\nIsrael needed help from the US, Britain, France and Jordan in countering a direct attack from Iran in April that involved some 150 missiles and 170 drones.\n\nLessons from previous Israeli interventions in Lebanon\n\nThe other factor - especially for wiser heads mindful of history - is the country's previous interventions in Lebanon have been far from cost-free.\n\nIsrael's problems with Lebanon started when the late King Hussein of Jordan forced the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO), then led by Yasser Arafat, to relocate to Lebanon in 1970. He did that because the PLO had been using Jordan as a base for operations against Israel after the 1967 war, provoking Israeli retaliation.\n\nFrom the early 1970s, the PLO formed a state within a state in Lebanon. It largely acted independently from the perennially weak Lebanese government, which was divided on sectarian grounds, and in 1975, collapsed into a prolonged civil war.\n\nThe PLO used southern Lebanon to launch attacks against Israel, leading Israel to launch a limited invasion of its northern neighbour in 1978, driving Palestinian militia groups north of the Litani River.\n\nThat invasion was only partially successful. Militants soon moved back towards the border and renewed their attacks on northern Israel. In 1982, then-Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin decided to remove the PLO entirely from Lebanon, launching a major invasion of Lebanon all the way to Beirut. This eventually forced the PLO leadership and the bulk of its fighters to relocate to Tunisia.\n\nDespite this success, the two Israeli invasions had the unintended consequence of radicalising the until-then quiescent Shia population of southern Lebanon.\n\nThat enabled Iran, in its early post-revolutionary phase under Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, to work with Shia clerics in Lebanon to establish Hezbollah (Party of God in Arabic), which became a greater threat to Israel than the PLO had ever been.\n\nBolstered by Iranian support, Hezbollah has become stronger over the years, becoming a force in Lebanese politics and regularly firing missiles into Israel.\n\nIn 2006, Hezbollah was able to block an IDF advance into southern Lebanon aimed at rescuing two Israeli soldiers Hezbollah had captured. The outcome was essentially a draw, and the two soldiers remained in captivity until their bodies were exchanged for Lebanese prisoners in 2008.\n\nMany Arab observers at the time judged that by surviving an asymmetrical conflict, Hezbollah had emerged with a political and military victory.\n\nFor a while during and after that conflict, Nasrallah was one of the most popular regional leaders, despite the fact he was loathed by rulers of conservative Sunni Arab states such as Saudi Arabia.\n\nWill history repeat itself?\n\nThis is the background to discussions in Israel about launching a war against Hezbollah. And it demonstrates how the quote from Churchill is relevant.\n\nMost military experts would caution against choosing to fight a war on two fronts. Former US President George W. Bush decided to invade Iraq in 2003 when the war in Afghanistan had not concluded. The outcome was hugely costly for the US military and disastrous for both countries.\n\nThe 19th century American writer Mark Twain is reported to have said that history does not repeat itself, but it often rhymes. Will Israel's leaders listen to the echoes of the past?\n\nIan Parmeter does not work for, consult, own shares in or receive funding from any company or organisation that would benefit from this article, and has disclosed no relevant affiliations beyond their academic appointment.\n\n/Courtesy of The Conversation. Others, including US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, have also pointed to the difficulty of destroying the Islamist group.\n\nAlso read Israel hits Gaza as tensions surge on Lebanon border US wants to avoid 'greater war' along Lebanon-Israel border, envoy says US envoy in Israel in bid to calm situation with Hezbollah Fighting in Gaza's Rafah as tensions soar on Israel-Lebanon border\n\nHezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah's group and Israeli forces have exchanged near-daily fire since Hamas's October 7 attack on southern Israel triggered the Gaza war, and the bellicose talk has lately escalated along with the strikes.\n\nIn a televised address, Nasrallah said \"no place\" in Israel would \"be spared our rockets\" if war began.\n\nThe chief of the Iran-backed group also threatened the nearby island nation of Cyprus if it opened its airports or bases to Israel \"to target Lebanon\".\n\nEuropean Union member Cyprus is home to two British bases, including an airbase, but they are in sovereign British territory and not controlled by the Cypriot government.\n\nOn Thursday the Cypriot government spokesman dismissed as \"totally groundless\" any suggestion of possible involvement in a conflict related to Lebanon.\n\n\"Cyprus is not involved, nor will it become involved, in any military conflicts,\" Konstantinos Letymbiotis told state radio.\n\nWarplanes from the British airbase in Cyprus have, along with US forces, carried out reprisal strikes against Yemen's Iran-backed Huthi rebels who have for months been attacking shipping in adjacent waterways.\n\n'Urgent' de-escalation\n\nOn Wednesday the US military said its forces destroyed two Houthi sites in Yemen.\n\nThe October Hamas attack on Israel resulted in the deaths of 1,194 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nThe militants also seized hostages, 116 of whom remain in Gaza although the army says 41 are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory offensive in Gaza has killed at least 37,431 people, also mostly civilians, according to the health ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory.\n\nThe latest toll on Thursday included at least 35 deaths over the previous day, the ministry said.\n\nThe Huthis and Hezbollah both say they are acting in response to Israel's actions in Gaza.\n\nOn Tuesday, Israel's military announced that \"operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon were approved and validated\".\n\nThe same day, Hezbollah published a video showing drone footage purportedly taken by the movement over northern Israel, including parts of Haifa's city and port.\n\nUS envoy Amos Hochstein has called for \"urgent\" de-escalation.\n\nThe cross-border violence has killed at least 479 people in Lebanon, most of them fighters but also 93 civilians, according to an AFP tally.\n\nIsraeli authorities say at least 15 soldiers and 11 civilians have been killed in the country's north.\n\nWeary residents of Beirut on Thursday downplayed the chances of war in Lebanon, which a political deadlock has left essentially leaderless while a five-year economic meltdown continues.\n\nIn Israel, some citizens called for action against Hezbollah, and Noam Galili, 29, said: \"I know what it is like to live close to Lebanon, but it never felt as dangerous as it does now.\"\n\nPressures\n\nThe violence has already displaced tens of thousands of people, mostly in Lebanon but also in northern Israel.\n\nIn southern Gaza, a United Nations mission found hundreds of thousands of displaced people \"suffer from poor access to shelter, health, food, water and sanitation,\" a UN report said late Wednesday.\n\nIn central Gaza, residents said they had turned to cooking oil to power their cars.\n\nUS President Joe Biden has called for the implementation of a ceasefire plan he outlined last month.\n\nHochstein and Washington's top diplomat, Blinken, say a deal to curb fighting in Gaza would by extension help resolve the Hezbollah-Israel violence.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's far-right coalition partners strongly oppose a Gaza ceasefire.\n\nHe is also facing regular street protests by tens of thousands demanding a deal to free the hostages, and accusing him of prolonging the war.\n\nThe Israeli military spokesman, Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari, on Wednesday told Israel's Channel 13: \"To say that we are going to make Hamas disappear is to throw sand in people's eyes. If we don't provide an alternative, in the end, we will have Hamas.\"\n\nHe said, \"Hamas is an ideology. We cannot eliminate an ideology.\"\n\nIsraeli government spokesman David Mencer said Thursday Hamas's \"final stronghold\" in Rafah on the border with Egypt is systematically being taken apart.\n\n\"And we will win,\" he told a press briefing.\n\nBlinken last month said Washington had not seen an Israeli post-war plan and \"the trajectory Israel is on\" would still leave thousands of {"uri": "8186459615", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "06:38:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T06:38:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T06:35:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://foreignaffairs.co.nz/2024/06/20/mil-evening-report-does-israel-really-want-to-open-a-two-front-war-by-attacking-hezbollah-in-lebanon/", "title": "MIL-Evening Report: Does Israel really want to open a two-front war by attacking Hezbollah...", "body": "Source: The Conversation (Au and NZ) - By Ian Parmeter, Research Scholar, Centre for Arab and Islamic Studies, Australian National University\n\nAmong the many sayings attributed to Winston Churchill is, \"Those who fail to learn from history are doomed to repeat it.\"\n\nThis sentiment seems appropriate as Israel potentially appears ready to embark on a war against the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah in southern Lebanon.\n\nIsraeli Foreign Minister Israel Katz said this week a decision on an all-out war against Hezbollah was \"coming soon\" and that senior commanders of the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) had signed off on a plan for the operation.\n\nThis threat comes despite the fact Israel's war against Hamas in Gaza is far from over. Israel has still not achieved the two primary objectives Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu put forth at the start of the conflict:\n\nIsrael has cogent reasons for wanting to eliminate the threat from Hezbollah. Hezbollah has been launching Iranian-supplied missiles, rockets and drones across the border into northern Israel since the Gaza war began on October 8. Its stated purpose is to support Hamas by distracting the IDF from its Gaza operation.\n\nHezbollah's attacks have been relatively circumscribed - confined so far to northern Israel. But they have led to the displacement of some 60,000 residents from the border area. These people are understandably fed up and demanding Netanyahu's government takes action to force Hezbollah to withdraw from the border.\n\nThis anger has been augmented this week by Hezbollah publicising video footage of military and civilian sites in the northern Israeli city of Haifa, which had been taken by a low-flying surveillance drone.\n\nThe implication: Hezbollah was scoping the region for new targets. Haifa, a city of nearly 300,000, has not yet been subject to Hezbollah attacks.\n\nThe most far-right members of Netanyahu's cabinet, Bezalel Smotrich and Itamar Ben Gvir, have openly called for Israel to invade southern Lebanon. Even without this pressure, Netanyahu has ample reason to want to neutralise the Hezbollah threat because residents of northern Israel are strong supporters of his Likud party.\n\nThe United States is obviously concerned about the risk Israel will open a second front in its conflicts. As such, President Joe Biden has sent an envoy, Amos Hochstein, to Israel and Lebanon to try to reduce tensions on both sides.\n\nIn Lebanon, he can't publicly deal directly with the Hezbollah leader, Hassan Nasrallah, because the group is on the US list of global terrorist organisations. Instead, he met the long-serving speaker of the Lebanese parliament, Nabih Berri, who as a fellow Shia is able to talk with Nasrallah.\n\nBut Hezbollah answers to Iran - its main backer in the region. And it's doubtful if any Lebanese leader can persuade it to desist from action approved by Iran.\n\nIran's interests in the potential for an Israel-Hezbollah war at this time are mixed. It would obviously be glad to see Israel under military pressure on two fronts. But Iranian leaders see Hezbollah as insurance against an Israeli attack on its nuclear facilities.\n\nHezbollah has an estimated 150,000 missiles and rockets, including some that could reach deep into Israel. So far, Iran seems to want Hezbollah to hold back from a major escalation with Israel, which could deplete most of that arsenal.\n\nThat said, although Israel's Iron Dome defensive shield has been remarkably successful in neutralising the rocket threat from Gaza, it might not be as effective against a large-scale barrage of more sophisticated missiles.\n\nIsrael needed help from the US, Britain, France and Jordan in countering a direct attack from Iran in April that involved some 150 missiles and 170 drones.\n\nThe other factor - especially for wiser heads mindful of history - is the country's previous interventions in Lebanon have been far from cost-free.\n\nIsrael's problems with Lebanon started when the late King Hussein of Jordan forced the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO), then led by Yasser Arafat, to relocate to Lebanon in 1970. He did that because the PLO had been using Jordan as a base for operations against Israel after the 1967 war, provoking Israeli retaliation.\n\nFrom the early 1970s, the PLO formed a state within a state in Lebanon. It largely acted independently from the perennially weak Lebanese government, which was divided on sectarian grounds, and in 1975, collapsed into a prolonged civil war.\n\nThe PLO used southern Lebanon to launch attacks against Israel, leading Israel to launch a limited invasion of its northern neighbour in 1978, driving Palestinian militia groups north of the Litani River.\n\nThat invasion was only partially successful. Militants soon moved back towards the border and renewed their attacks on northern Israel. In 1982, then-Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin decided to remove the PLO entirely from Lebanon, launching a major invasion of Lebanon all the way to Beirut. This eventually forced the PLO leadership and the bulk of its fighters to relocate to Tunisia.\n\nDespite this success, the two Israeli invasions had the unintended consequence of radicalising the until-then quiescent Shia population of southern Lebanon.\n\nThat enabled Iran, in its early post-revolutionary phase under Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, to work with Shia clerics in Lebanon to establish Hezbollah (Party of God in Arabic), which became a greater threat to Israel than the PLO had ever been.\n\nBolstered by Iranian support, Hezbollah has become stronger over the years, becoming a force in Lebanese politics and regularly firing missiles into Israel.\n\nIn 2006, Hezbollah was able to block an IDF advance into southern Lebanon aimed at rescuing two Israeli soldiers Hezbollah had captured. The outcome was essentially a draw, and the two soldiers remained in captivity until their bodies were exchanged for Lebanese prisoners in 2008.\n\nMany Arab observers at the time judged that by surviving an asymmetrical conflict, Hezbollah had emerged with a political and military victory.\n\nFor a while during and after that conflict, Nasrallah was one of the most popular regional leaders, despite the fact he was loathed by rulers of conservative Sunni Arab states such as Saudi Arabia.\n\nThis is the background to discussions in Israel about launching a war against Hezbollah. And it demonstrates how the quote from Churchill is relevant.\n\nMost military experts would caution against choosing to fight a war on two fronts. Former US President George W. Bush decided to invade Iraq in 2003 when the war in Afghanistan had not concluded. The outcome was hugely costly for the US military and disastrous for both countries.\n\nThe 19th century American writer Mark Twain is reported to have said that history does not repeat itself, but it often rhymes. Will Israel's leaders listen to the echoes of the past?\n\nIan Parmeter does not work for, consult, own shares in or receive funding from any company or organisation that would benefit from this article, and has disclosed no relevant affiliations beyond their academic appointment.", "source": {"uri": "foreignaffairs.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "foreignaffairs.co.nz"}, "authors": Effectiveness of Hezbollah Strikes against Israel - World news - Tasnim News Agency", "body": "Delivering a televised speech at a Wednesday funeral ceremony held in commemoration of several Hezbollah fighters fallen in recent Israeli airstrikes in southern Lebanon, Seyed Hassan Nasrallah said enemies are trying to create the absurd notion that the Lebanese resistance group's strikes against Israeli military positions in the northern side of the 1948 occupied territories are unrelated to the bloody onslaught on Gaza.\n\nHezbollah's retaliatory strikes have played a pivotal role in the course of the struggle against Israel, he stated.\n\nHe said the strikes have inflicted material, moral and psychological losses on the occupying regime.\n\n\"One of the strongest indications of the effectiveness of the Lebanese front is the outcry, threats and intimidation we hear from Israeli authorities as well as illegal settlers,\" Nasrallah said.\n\n\"If this front were not effective, why are certain international parties seeking to detach it from the Gaza conflict?\"\n\nNasrallah then paid homage to high-ranking Hezbollah field commander Sami Abdallah, better known by the nom the guerre Abu Taleb, who was killed in Israeli airstrikes against a house in Lebanon's southern town of Jwaya last week.\n\nThe Hezbollah chief went on to highlight the spiritual gift of martyrdom, stating that Abu Taleb played an important role in the Lebanese resistance group.\n\nHe said Hezbollah is now more determined to confront the Zionist enemy, terming his group's response to the latest Israeli strikes as \"fairly strong and befitting.\"\n\nNasrallah underscored that Hezbollah's publication of a video footage gathered from its surveillance aircraft of strategic locations in the northern part of the occupied territories, including sea and air ports in the city of Haifa, was part of the group's psychological warfare against the Tel Aviv regime.\n\n\"We have long hours of footage of Haifa, what's around it, what's before it, what's beyond it and what's even further,\" he said.\n\nThe Hezbollah chief added that Israel doesn't disclose the real number of its fatalities in Gaza, as it avoids announcing its losses resulting from Hezbollah attacks in an attempt to deflect criticism away from prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu.\n\nNasrallah also roundly dismissed the the Arabian Sea, stating that the strikes continue unabated regardless of the US intelligence agencies' attempts to stop them.\n\n\"The United States and Britain have failed to stop Yemeni attacks. The Zionist enemy, unable to engage in other fronts, relies on US and UK support to confront Yemeni forces.\n\n\"Israeli officials are trying to paint a distorted picture of unfolding developments in Gaza in order to mislead the public opinion and falsely claim to have made achievements,\" Nasrallah said, according to Press TV.\n\nHe stated that Hezbollah is in possession of a large cache of advanced weapons, and that the resistance movement is manufacturing its own combat drones as well as some types of rockets.\n\n\"The resistance's manpower is unprecedented. We have recruited over 100,000 fighters,\" the Hezbollah leader said, warning that \"no place\" in the Israeli-occupied territories would be spared from the group's weapons in case of a full-blown {"uri": "8186775572", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:03:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:03:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:02:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.al-monitor.com/originals/2024/06/israel-hezbollah-tensions-drive-fears-widening-gaza-war", "title": "Israel-Hezbollah tensions drive fears of widening Gaza war", "body": "An Israeli firefighter and a resident take cover as sirens warn of rockets launched from southern Lebanon, in Kiryat Shmona, northern Israel - Jalaa MAREY\n\nFears of a regional war rose Thursday after Lebanon's powerful Hezbollah movement said none of Israel would be spared in a full-blown conflict, and Israel said it had approved plans for a Lebanon offensive.\n\nExperts are divided on the prospect of wider war, almost nine months into Israel's vow to eradicate Hamas, the Palestinian militant group in the Gaza Strip.\n\nOn Wednesday Israel's top army spokesman said Hamas, as an ideology, cannot be eliminated. Others, including US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, have also pointed to the difficulty of destroying the Islamist group.\n\nIn a televised address, Hezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah said \"no place\" in Israel would \"be spared our rockets\" if war began.\n\nNasrallah's Iran-backed group has exchanged near-daily fire with Israel since Hamas's October 7 attack on southern Israel, but the fire from Hezbollah rockets, Israeli warplanes and other weapons has escalated in the past few weeks.\n\nThe Hezbollah chief also threatened the nearby island nation of Cyprus if it opened its airports or bases to Israel \"to target Lebanon\".\n\nCyprus, a European Union member, is home to two British bases, including an airbase, but they are in sovereign British territory and not controlled by the Cypriot government.\n\nCypriot President Nikos Christodoulides denied his country's involvement in the war and said it was \"part of the solution\". He pointed to its role in a maritime humanitarian corridor to Gaza.\n\nWarplanes from the British airbase in Cyprus have, along with United States forces, carried out reprisal strikes against Yemen's Iran-backed Huthi rebels who have for months been attacking shipping in nearby waterways.\n\n- Hundreds killed -\n\nOn Wednesday the US military said its forces destroyed two Huthi sites in Yemen.\n\nThe unprecedented October 7 attack by Hamas that triggered the Gaza war resulted in the deaths of 1,194 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nThe militants also seized hostages, 116 of whom remain in Gaza although the army says 41 are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory offensive in Gaza has killed at least 37,396 people, also mostly civilians, according to the health ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory.\n\nThe Huthis and Hezbollah both say they are acting in response to Israel's actions in Gaza.\n\nOn Tuesday Israel's military announced that \"operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon were approved and validated\", and Foreign Minister Israel Katz warned of Hezbollah's destruction in a \"total war\".\n\nUS envoy Amos Hochstein called for \"urgent\" de-escalation.\n\nOn Tuesday Hezbollah published a more than nine-minute video showing drone footage purportedly taken by the movement over northern Israel, including parts of the city and port of Haifa.\n\nTwo former Israeli security officials were split on the prospect of wider conflict.\n\nOne told AFP there would be an operation in Lebanon \"within a few weeks\" while another said the government was \"more interested in a ceasefire\".\n\nThe cross-border violence has killed at least 478 people in Lebanon, most of them fighters but also 93 civilians, according to an AFP tally.\n\nIsraeli authorities say at least 15 soldiers and 11 civilians have been killed in the country's north.\n\n- South Gaza aid 'deterioration' -\n\nTens of thousands have been displaced on the Israeli side of the frontier, and the UN's International Organization for Migration says more than 95,000 have been uprooted in Lebanon.\n\nIn southern Gaza, a United Nations assessment mission found hundreds of thousands of displaced people \"suffer from poor access to shelter, health, food, water and sanitation,\" a UN report said late Wednesday.\n\nUN deputy spokesman Farhan Haq said there had been \"an improvement\" in aid reaching northern Gaza \"but a drastic deterioration in the south\".\n\nUS President Joe Biden has called for the implementation of a ceasefire plan he outlined last month.\n\nHochstein said the plan would ultimately lead to the end of the Gaza conflict, which would in turn quell fighting between Israel and Hezbollah.\n\nOn a Middle East tour earlier this month, Washington's top diplomat, Blinken, similarly said \"the best way\" to help resolve the Hezbollah-Israel violence was resolution of the Gaza fighting.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's far-right coalition partners strongly oppose a ceasefire.\n\nHe is also facing regular street protests by tens of thousands demanding a deal to free the hostages, and accusing him of prolonging the war.\n\nThe Israeli military spokesman, Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari, on Wednesday said that, \"To say that we are going to make Hamas disappear is to throw sand in people's eyes. If we don't provide an alternative, in the end, we will have Hamas.\"\n\nSpeaking to Israel's Channel 13, he said: \"Hamas is an ideology, we cannot eliminate an ideology.\"\n\nBlinken last month told US TV that the United States had not seen an Israeli post-war plan and \"the trajectory Israel is on\" would still leave thousands of Hamas fighters.", "source": {"uri": "al-monitor.com", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-06-395764968", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:42:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:42:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T09:57:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com.au/israel-hezbollah-tensions-drive-fears-widening-gaza-war-1848784", "title": "Israel-Hezbollah Tensions Drive Fears Of Widening Gaza War", "body": "Fears of a regional war rose Thursday after Lebanon's powerful Hezbollah movement said none of Israel would be spared in a full-blown conflict, and Israel said it had approved plans for a Lebanon offensive.\n\nExperts are divided on the prospect of wider war, almost nine months into Israel's vow to eradicate Hamas, the Palestinian militant group in the Gaza Strip.\n\nOn Wednesday Israel's top army spokesman said Hamas, as an ideology, cannot be eliminated. Others, including US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, have also pointed to the difficulty of destroying the Islamist group.\n\nIn a televised address, Hezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah said \"no place\" in Israel would \"be spared our rockets\" if war began.\n\nNasrallah's Iran-backed group has exchanged near-daily fire with Israel since Hamas's October 7 attack on southern Israel, but the fire from Hezbollah rockets, Israeli warplanes and other weapons has escalated in the past few weeks.\n\nThe Hezbollah chief also threatened the nearby island nation of Cyprus if it opened its airports or bases to Israel \"to target Lebanon\".\n\nCyprus, a European Union member, is home to two British bases, including an airbase, but they are in sovereign British territory and not controlled by the Cypriot government.\n\nCypriot President Nikos Christodoulides denied his country's involvement in the war and said it was \"part of the solution\". He pointed to its role in a maritime humanitarian corridor to Gaza.\n\nWarplanes from the British airbase in Cyprus have, along with United States forces, carried out reprisal strikes against Yemen's Iran-backed Huthi rebels who have for months been attacking shipping in nearby waterways.\n\nOn Wednesday the US military said its forces destroyed two Huthi sites in Yemen.\n\nThe unprecedented October 7 attack by Hamas that triggered the Gaza war resulted in the deaths of 1,194 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nThe militants also seized hostages, 116 of whom remain in Gaza although the army says 41 are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory offensive in Gaza has killed at least 37,396 people, also mostly civilians, according to the health ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory.\n\nThe Huthis and Hezbollah both say they are acting in response to Israel's actions in Gaza.\n\nOn Tuesday Israel's military announced that \"operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon were approved and validated\", and Foreign Minister Israel Katz warned of Hezbollah's destruction in a \"total war\".\n\nUS envoy Amos Hochstein called for \"urgent\" de-escalation.\n\nOn Tuesday Hezbollah published a more than nine-minute video showing drone footage purportedly taken by the movement over northern Israel, including parts of the city and port of Haifa.\n\nTwo former Israeli security officials were split on the prospect of wider conflict.\n\nOne told AFP there would be an operation in Lebanon \"within a few weeks\" while another said the government was \"more interested in a ceasefire\".\n\nThe cross-border violence has killed at least 478 people in Lebanon, most of them fighters but also 93 civilians, according to an AFP tally.\n\nIsraeli authorities say at least 15 soldiers and 11 civilians have been killed in the country's north.\n\nTens of thousands have been displaced on the Israeli side of the frontier, and the UN's International Organization for Migration says more than 95,000 have been uprooted in Lebanon.\n\nUN deputy spokesman Farhan Haq said there had been \"an improvement\" in aid reaching northern Gaza \"but a drastic deterioration in the south\".\n\nUS President Joe Biden has called for the implementation of a ceasefire plan he outlined last month.\n\nHochstein said the plan would ultimately lead to the end of the Gaza conflict, which would in turn quell fighting between Israel and Hezbollah.\n\nOn a Middle East tour earlier this month, Washington's top diplomat, Blinken, similarly said \"the best way\" to help resolve the Hezbollah-Israel violence was resolution of the Gaza fighting.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's far-right coalition partners strongly oppose a ceasefire.\n\nHe is also facing regular street protests by tens of thousands demanding a deal to free the hostages, and accusing him of prolonging the war.\n\nThe Israeli military spokesman, Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari, on Wednesday said that, \"To say that we are going to make Hamas disappear is to throw sand in people's eyes. If we don't provide an alternative, in the end, we will have Hamas.\"\n\nSpeaking to Israel's Channel 13, he said: \"Hamas is an ideology, we cannot eliminate an ideology.\"\n\nBlinken last month told Others, including US secretary of state Antony Blinken, have also pointed to the difficulty of destroying the Islamist group.\n\nHezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah's group and Israeli forces have exchanged near-daily fire since Hamas's October 7 attack on southern Israel triggered the Gaza war, and the bellicose talk has lately escalated along with the strikes.\n\nIn a televised address, Nasrallah said 'no place' in Israel would 'be spared our rockets' if war began.\n\nThe chief of the Iran-backed group also threatened the nearby island nation of Cyprus if it opened its airports or bases to Israel 'to target Lebanon'.\n\nEuropean Union member Cyprus is home to two British bases, including an airbase, but they are in sovereign British territory and not controlled by the Cypriot government.\n\nOn Thursday the Cypriot government spokesman dismissed as 'totally groundless' any suggestion of possible involvement in a conflict related to Lebanon.\n\n'Cyprus is not involved, nor will it become involved, in any military conflicts,' Konstantinos Letymbiotis told state radio.\n\nWarplanes from the British airbase in Cyprus have, along with US forces, carried out reprisal strikes against Yemen's Iran-backed Huthi rebels who have for months been attacking shipping in adjacent waterways.\n\nOn Wednesday the US military said its forces destroyed two Huthi sites in Yemen.\n\nThe October Hamas attack on Israel resulted in the deaths of 1,194 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nThe militants also seized hostages, 116 of whom remain in Gaza although the army says 41 are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory offensive in Gaza has killed at least 37,431 people, also mostly civilians, according to the health ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory.\n\nThe latest toll on Thursday included at least 35 deaths over the previous day, the ministry said.\n\nThe Huthis and Hezbollah both say they are acting in response to Israel's actions in Gaza.\n\nOn Tuesday, Israel's military announced that 'operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon were approved and validated'.\n\nThe same day, Hezbollah published a video showing drone footage purportedly taken by the movement over northern Israel, including parts of Haifa's city and port.\n\nUS envoy Amos Hochstein has called for 'urgent' de-escalation.\n\nThe cross-border violence has killed at least 479 people in Lebanon, most of them fighters but also 93 civilians, according to an AFP tally.\n\nIsraeli authorities say at least 15 soldiers and 11 civilians have been killed in the country's north.\n\nWeary residents of Beirut on Thursday downplayed the chances of war in Lebanon, which a political deadlock has left essentially leaderless while a five-year economic meltdown continues.\n\nIn Israel, some citizens called for action against Hezbollah, and Noam Galili, 29, said: 'I know what it is like to live close to Lebanon, but it never felt as dangerous as it does now.'\n\nThe violence has already displaced tens of thousands of people, mostly in Lebanon but also in northern Israel.\n\nIn southern Gaza, a United Nations mission found hundreds of thousands of displaced people 'suffer from poor access to shelter, health, food, water and sanitation,' a UN report said late Wednesday.\n\nIn central Gaza, residents said they had turned to cooking oil to power their cars.\n\nUS president Joe Biden has called for the implementation of a ceasefire plan he outlined last month.\n\nHochstein and Washington's top diplomat, Blinken, say a deal to curb fighting in Gaza would by extension help resolve the Hezbollah-Israel violence.\n\nIsraeli prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu's far-right coalition partners strongly oppose a Gaza ceasefire.\n\nHe is also facing regular street protests by tens of thousands demanding a deal to free the hostages, and accusing him of prolonging the war.\n\nThe Israeli military spokesman, Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari, on Wednesday told Israel's Channel 13: 'To say that we are going to make Hamas disappear is to throw sand in people's eyes. If we don't provide an alternative, in the end, we will have Hamas.'\n\nHe said, 'Hamas is an ideology. We cannot eliminate an ideology.'\n\nIsraeli government spokesman David Mencer said Thursday Hamas's 'final stronghold' in Rafah on the border with Egypt is systematically being taken apart.\n\n'And we will win,' he told a press briefing.\n\nBlinken last month said Washington had not seen an Israeli post-war plan and 'the trajectory Israel is on' would still leave thousands of Hamas fighters.", The international community is desperately seeking to avoid a regional conflict.\n\nOn Tuesday, Hezbollah released a nine-minute video of drone footage from a drone that purportedly flew over Israel. The video was a thinly veiled threat as Hezbollah demonstrates its capabilities.\n\nRich Goldberg, a senior adviser for the Foundation for Defense of Democracies, told the Washington Examiner, \"Hezbollah has been testing in the last couple of weeks in particular, as they've been escalating, and to some extent, the Israeli air defense has failed,\" adding that \"it's not clear that Israel's air defenses are fully up to the job of intercepting and defeating swarm drones, and I think Hezbollah knows that.\"\n\nNasrallah claimed the group has \"greatly exceeded\" 100,000 troops.\n\nIsrael's foreign minister, Israel Katz, said in response to the video, \"We are very close to the moment of decision to change the rules against Hezbollah and Lebanon. {"uri": "8186786233", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:10:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:10:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:08:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-13550343/Israel-Hezbollah-tensions-drive-fears-widening-Gaza-war.html", "title": "Israel-Hezbollah tensions drive fears of widening Gaza war", "body": "An Israeli firefighter and a resident take cover as sirens warn of rockets launched from southern Lebanon, in Kiryat Shmona, northern Israel\n\nFears of a regional war rose Thursday after Lebanon's powerful Hezbollah movement said none of Israel would be spared in a full-blown conflict, and Israel said it had approved plans for a Lebanon offensive.\n\nExperts are divided on the prospect of wider war, almost nine months into Israel's vow to eradicate Hamas, the Palestinian militant group in the Gaza Strip.\n\nOn Wednesday Israel's top army spokesman said Hamas, as an ideology, cannot be eliminated. Others, including US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, have also pointed to the difficulty of destroying the Islamist group.\n\nIn a televised address, Hezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah said \"no place\" in Israel would \"be spared our rockets\" if war began.\n\nNasrallah's Iran-backed group has exchanged near-daily fire with Israel since Hamas's October 7 attack on southern Israel, but the fire from Hezbollah rockets, Israeli warplanes and other weapons has escalated in the past few weeks.\n\nThe Hezbollah chief also threatened the nearby island nation of Cyprus if it opened its airports or bases to Israel \"to target Lebanon\".\n\nBeachgoers frolic at Lady's Mile in Limassol, Cyprus, as a Eurofighter Typhoon lands at nearby Royal Air Force (RAF) base Akrotiri, on sovereign British territory\n\nCyprus, a European Union member, is home to two British bases, including an airbase, but they are in sovereign British territory and not controlled by the Cypriot government.\n\nCypriot President Nikos Christodoulides denied his country's involvement in the war and said it was \"part of the solution\". He pointed to its role in a maritime humanitarian corridor to Gaza.\n\nWarplanes from the British airbase in Cyprus have, along with United States forces, carried out reprisal strikes against Yemen's Iran-backed Huthi rebels who have for months been attacking shipping in nearby waterways.\n\n- Hundreds killed -\n\nOn Wednesday the US military said its forces destroyed two Huthi sites in Yemen.\n\nThe unprecedented October 7 attack by Hamas that triggered the Gaza war resulted in the deaths of 1,194 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nThe border area between Lebanon and Israel\n\nThe militants also seized hostages, 116 of whom remain in Gaza although the army says 41 are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory offensive in Gaza has killed at least 37,396 people, also mostly civilians, according to the health ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory.\n\nThe Huthis and Hezbollah both say they are acting in response to Israel's actions in Gaza.\n\nOn Tuesday Israel's military announced that \"operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon were approved and validated\", and Foreign Minister Israel Katz warned of Hezbollah's destruction in a \"total war\".\n\nUS envoy Amos Hochstein called for \"urgent\" de-escalation.\n\nOn Tuesday Hezbollah published a more than nine-minute video showing drone footage purportedly taken by the movement over northern Israel, including parts of the city and port of Haifa.\n\nTwo former Israeli security officials were split on the prospect of wider conflict.\n\nOne told AFP there would be an operation in Lebanon \"within a few weeks\" while another said the government was \"more interested in a ceasefire\".\n\nThe cross-border violence has killed at least 478 people in Lebanon, most of them fighters but also 93 civilians, according to an AFP tally.\n\nIsraeli authorities say at least 15 soldiers and 11 civilians have been killed in the country's north.\n\n- South Gaza aid 'deterioration' -\n\nTens of thousands have been displaced on the Israeli side of the frontier, and the UN's International Organization for Migration says more than 95,000 have been uprooted in Lebanon.\n\nIn southern Gaza, a United Nations assessment mission found hundreds of thousands of displaced people \"suffer from poor access to shelter, health, food, water and sanitation,\" a UN report said late Wednesday.\n\nUN deputy spokesman Farhan Haq said there had been \"an improvement\" in aid reaching northern Gaza \"but a drastic deterioration in the south\".\n\nUS President Joe Biden has called for the implementation of a ceasefire plan he outlined last month.\n\nHochstein said the plan would ultimately lead to the end of the Gaza conflict, which would in turn quell fighting between Israel and Hezbollah.\n\nOn a Middle East tour earlier this month, Washington's top diplomat, Blinken, similarly said \"the best way\" to help resolve the Hezbollah-Israel violence was resolution of the Gaza fighting.\n\nPalestinian families pack to leave Rafah for Khan Yunis, southern Gaza -- the UN says more than one million people have been forced from Rafah since early May 2024 when an Israeli ground operation began there\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's far-right coalition partners strongly oppose a ceasefire.\n\nHe is also facing regular street protests by tens of thousands demanding a deal to free the hostages, and accusing him of prolonging the war.\n\nThe Israeli military spokesman, Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari, on Wednesday said that, \"To say that we Others, including U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken, have also pointed to the difficulty of destroying the group.\n\nIn a televised address, Hezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah said \"no place\" in Israel would \"be spared our rockets\" if war began.\n\nNasrallah's Iran-backed group has exchanged near-daily fire with Israel since Hamas's Oct. 7 attack on southern Israel, but the fire from Hezbollah rockets, Israeli warplanes and other weapons has escalated in the past few weeks.\n\nThe Hezbollah chief also threatened the nearby island nation, Greek Cyprus, if it opened its airports or bases to Israel \"to target Lebanon\".\n\nGreek Cyprus, a European Union member, is home to two British bases, including an airbase, but they are in sovereign British territory and not controlled by the Cypriot government.\n\nGreek Cypriot President Nikos Christodoulides denied his country's involvement in the war and said it was \"part of the solution\". He pointed to its role in a maritime humanitarian corridor to Gaza.\n\nWarplanes from the British airbase in Cyprus have, along with United States forces, carried out reprisal strikes against Yemen's Iran-backed Huthi rebels who have for months been attacking shipping in nearby waterways.\n\nHundreds killed\n\nOn Wednesday the U.S. military said its forces destroyed two Huthi sites in Yemen.\n\nIsrael launched its war on Gaza in retaliation for the Hamas' Oct. 7 attacks that resulted in the deaths of more than 1,190 people, mostly civilians, according to Israeli official figures.\n\nHamas seized 251 hostages. Of these 116 remain in Gaza, although the army says 41 of them are dead.\n\nIsrael's offensive has killed at least 37,396 people in Gaza, mostly civilians, according to the Hamas-run territory's health ministry.\n\nThe Huthis and Hezbollah both say they are acting in response to Israel's actions in Gaza.\n\nOn Tuesday Israel's military announced that \"operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon were approved and validated\", and Foreign Minister Israel Katz warned of Hezbollah's destruction in a \"total war\".\n\nU.S. envoy Amos Hochstein called for \"urgent\" de-escalation.\n\nOn Tuesday Hezbollah published a more than nine-minute video showing drone footage purportedly taken by the movement over northern Israel, including parts of the city and port of Haifa.\n\nTwo former Israeli security officials were split on the prospect of wider conflict.\n\nOne told AFP there would be an operation in Lebanon \"within a few weeks\" while another said the government was \"more interested in a ceasefire\".\n\nThe cross-border violence has killed at least 478 people in Lebanon, most of them fighters but also 93 civilians, according to an AFP tally.\n\nIsraeli authorities say at least 15 soldiers and 11 civilians have been killed in the country's north.\n\nSouth Gaza aid 'deterioration'\n\nTens of thousands have been displaced on the Israeli side of the frontier, and the U.N.'s International Organization for Migration says more than 95,000 have been uprooted in Lebanon.\n\nIn southern Gaza, a United Nations assessment mission found hundreds of thousands of displaced people \"suffer from poor access to shelter, health, food, water and sanitation,\" a U.N. report said late Wednesday.\n\nU.N. deputy spokesman Farhan Haq said there had been \"an improvement\" in aid reaching northern Gaza \"but a drastic deterioration in the south\".\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden has called for the implementation of a ceasefire plan he outlined last month.\n\nHochstein said the plan would ultimately lead to the end of the Gaza conflict, which would in turn quell fighting between Israel and Hezbollah.\n\nOn a Middle East tour earlier this month, Washington's top diplomat, Blinken, similarly said \"the best way\" to help resolve the Hezbollah-Israel violence was resolution of the Gaza fighting.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's far-right coalition partners strongly oppose a ceasefire.\n\nHe is also facing regular street protests by tens of thousands demanding a deal to free the hostages, and accusing him of prolonging the war.\n\nThe Israeli military {"uri": "8186517509", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "07:18:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T07:18:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T07:17:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.thenationalnews.com/news/mena/2024/06/20/lebanon-israel-war/", "title": "Lebanon and Israel 'one mistake' from war that could devastate both countries", "body": "Israel and Hezbollah could be one false move from starting a devastating war that neither wants, experts and security officials have told The National.\n\nBoth sides have been escalating their rocket fire and air strikes for weeks, sparking fears that the conflict is about to break into all-out war.\n\nAccording to one Lebanese official aligned with Hezbollah, the war has already started.\n\n\"If you compare the start to now, it is a war. The Israelis ... they are everywhere. Their escalation shows that they want Lebanon engaged into war,\" he told The National.\n\nThe Israeli military and Hezbollah possess vast arsenals that would eclipse the damage from their last war in 2006.\n\nHezbollah is thought to have up to 150,000 rockets - enough to fire up to 1,500 a day, by some estimates, compared to about 15,000 in 2006.\n\nIsrael, meanwhile, has one of the largest air forces in the world, responsible for laying waste to most of Gaza, where almost 37,400 Palestinians have been killed since war began on October 7, according to local health officials.\n\nIt was sparked by Hamas-led attacks on southern Israel that killed 1,200 people.\n\nKarim El Mufti, a professor of international relations at Sciences Po Paris, said: \"The 2006 war is small compared to what this is, and what this could ignite into.\"\n\nThe month-long war that year, sparked by a Hezbollah cross-border raid, led to more than 1,200 people in Lebanon being killed and about $5 billion in damage to the country.\n\nAbout 120 Israeli soldiers and 40 civilians were killed in Israel, while nearly half a million Israelis and one million Lebanese were displaced.\n\nThe sharp rise in attacks in recent weeks has led to fears of a return to 2006, only far worse.\n\nIsrael wants to remove the security threat posed by Hezbollah so about 60,000 displaced residents can return home near the border, while the Lebanese armed movement said it will not cease its attacks until Israel ends its bombardment of the Gaza Strip.\n\nIt said it does not want a full-scale war but is prepared for one.\n\nThe Hezbollah-aligned official said that Lebanon wants Israel to abide by UN Resolution 1701, which brought to an end the 2006 war between Hezbollah and Israel - even if it has never been fully implemented in the 18 years since.\n\nWhile Lebanon and Israel are technically enemy states, and the Lebanese government has repeatedly criticised Israel's actions in Gaza, Beirut has said it does not want a war but has little control over Hezbollah.\n\nLebanon accuses Israel of regularly breaching the terms of Resolution 1701 - whether by launching attacks on Israel, infringing on the country's territory, or occupying land claimed by Beirut.\n\n\"[The Israelis] are always escalating, not only by the border,\" the official said. \"They are targeting all of Lebanon. It's clear the Israelis are looking to get Lebanon engaged with this war. Lebanon does not want this war.\"\n\nOn the other side, Israel would point to the fact that UNSC 1701 also calls for the disarmament of non-state militias - a reference to Hezbollah.\n\nIsrael has vowed to push Hezbollah north of the Litani River, which the armed group firmly opposes.\n\nThe risk of escalation has led to a diplomatic effort by foreign powers, including the US and France, to avoid war.\n\nUS envoy Amos Hochstein visited Lebanon and Israel this week. He said it was both \"achievable\" and \"urgent\" that a resolution be achieved.\n\nHe also said that the US's ceasefire proposal for Gaza \"provides an opportunity to end the conflict\" in the Israel-Lebanon border area.\n\nThe US has been pressing Israel and Hamas to formally accept the ceasefire deal approved by UN Security Council members, which would allow an initial six-week pause to fighting.\n\nHezbollah said it will not end its attacks until there is a ceasefire in Gaza.\n\nThe Hezbollah-aligned official also accused Israel of refusing to agree to the ceasefire, while repeating the accusation often levelled at Benjamin Netanyahu that the Israeli Prime Minister seeks to prolong his stay in office by attacking Lebanon.\n\nIsrael has not formally said it supports the ceasefire proposal. Hamas has made positive indications while also submitting requested changes.\n\n\"We didn't hear from Netanyahu or [Israeli Defence Minister Yoav] Gallant that they have accepted,\" said the Lebanese official.\n\n\"If you look at warfare strategy throughout modern history, this is one of the most controlled escalations ever,\" Prof El Mufti told The National.\n\n\"But the Pandora's Box is open in Gaza and unless that front is closed there's going to be a potential explosion between Hezbollah and Israel.\"\n\nWhile a ceasefire in Gaza is seen as the best chance of defusing tension on the Lebanese border, some experts have warned that the long-standing tension between Hezbollah and Israel will remain regardless.\n\nThe tens of thousands of residents on either side of the border who have been displaced from their homes might say that war has already begun.\n\nBoth sides have expanded the scope and intensity of their attacks - with Hezbollah using ever more advanced weaponry and Israel hitting as far as Lebanon's northern border with Syria on the other side of the country.\n\nThe Lebanese official aligned said that Israeli escalation showed it wanted \"Lebanon engaged into war\".\n\nUN officials in Lebanon recently said that the risk of miscalculation remained high, a view heard elsewhere in the region.\n\n\"One mistake is a rocket hitting a bus full of school kids. That's World War Three and Four all together,\" said Lior Shelef, an Israeli army reservist, who lives in Kibbutz Snir, a few kilometres from the Lebanese border.\n\n\"It's what will happen when this one mistake happens and it will happen eventually. It's just a question of when.\n\n\"When the game was in the buffer zone inside Lebanon, we could make sure that we're not making mistakes from our side. And if they're going to make mistakes, they're going to suffer the consequences.\n\n\"The problem is that today a mistake that will happen here can be severe. And the problem is that it will be very hard for us to convince people to come back and live here.\"\n\nWhile the risk of miscalculation remains high, Prof El Mufti said there were too many parameters to consider to know what \"the straw that breaks the camel's back\" would be.\n\n\"This is very new for Israel. They don't have solutions and they're unable to think outside the box,\" he added.\n\n\"They only have violent solutions that won't work in this case.\" For this reason \"the Israelis will lose it first given how Hezbollah has behaved throughout the conflict\".\n\n\"I don't see Hezbollah overreacting because they have more to lose than the Israelis,\" Prof El Mufti said.\n\nDespite losing about 300 fighters, Hezbollah has maintained a policy of restraint since October 8, when it launched its first attack on Israeli positions.\n\nMeanwhile, Israel is more likely to be a catalyst for an all-out war \"because they have nothing to lose\", Prof El Mufti said.\n\n\"They've already broken so many boundaries regarding their relationship to the US and the world's perception of them, disengaging with international law and the ICJ and ICC ... and getting away with it so far.\n\n\"They've been avoiding civilian targets, showing they abide by international law even though they are not recognised internationally as a resistance except by [its allies] and the Lebanese state.\"\n\nWith strong Iranian backing, Hezbollah is also eager to re-establish deterrence. On Tuesday the group released drone footage deep in Israeli territory, over the port city of Haifa and nearby cities.\n\nThe drone had filmed Israeli military and civilian locations, sending a powerful reminder that the group is capable of doing much more damage in Israel than it did in 2006 - but that it has thus far restrained itself.", "source": {"uri": "thenationalnews.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8187592567", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:16:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:16:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:12:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/israelhezbollah-tensions-drive-fears-of-widening-gaza-war-101718909417178.html", "title": "Israel-Hezbollah tensions drive fears of widening Gaza war", "body": "Hezbollah said it fired dozens of rockets into northern Israel in retaliation for a deadly air strike in south Lebanon that Israel said killed a Hezbollah operative.\n\nHezbollah also claimed several other attacks on Israeli troops and positions on Thursday.\n\nExperts are divided on the prospect of wider war, almost nine months into Israel's vow to eradicate Hamas, the Palestinian militant group in the Gaza Strip.\n\nHezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah's group and Israeli forces have exchanged near-daily fire since Hamas's October 7 attack on southern Israel triggered the Gaza war, and the bellicose talk has escalated along with the strikes.\n\nIn a televised address, Nasrallah said \"no place\" in Israel would \"be spared our rockets\" if a wider war began.\n\nThe chief of the Iran-backed group also threatened nearby Cyprus if it opened its airports or bases to Israel \"to target Lebanon\".\n\nEuropean Union member Cyprus houses two British bases, including an airbase, but they are in sovereign British territory and not controlled by the Cypriot government.\n\nOn Thursday Cyprus government spokesman Konstantinos Letymbiotis dismissed as \"totally groundless\" any suggestion of possible involvement in a conflict related to Lebanon.\n\nWarplanes from the British airbase in Cyprus have, along with US forces, attacked Yemen's Iran-backed Huthi rebels who have for months been targeting Red Sea shipping.\n\nOn Wednesday the US military said its forces destroyed two Huthi sites in Yemen.\n\nThe October Hamas attack on Israel resulted in the deaths of 1,194 people, mostly civilians, according to an AFP tally based on Israeli official figures.\n\nThe militants also seized hostages, 116 of whom remain in Gaza although the army says 41 are dead.\n\nIsrael's retaliatory offensive in Gaza has killed at least 37,431 people, also mostly civilians, according to the health ministry in the Hamas-ruled territory.\n\nThe latest toll on Thursday included at least 35 deaths over the previous day, the ministry said.\n\nThe Huthis and Hezbollah both say they are acting in response to Israel's actions in Gaza.\n\nOn Tuesday, Israel's military announced that \"operational plans for an offensive in Lebanon were approved and validated\".\n\nThe same day, Hezbollah published a video showing drone footage it purportedly recorded over northern Israel, including parts of Haifa's city and port.\n\nUS envoy Amos Hochstein has called for \"urgent\" de-escalation, while the UN special coordinator for Lebanon Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert said there was \"no inevitability to conflict\" as she visited UN peacekeepers in south Lebanon.\n\nThe cross-border violence has killed at least 479 people in Lebanon, most of them fighters but also 93 civilians, according to an AFP tally.\n\nIsraeli authorities say at least 15 soldiers and 11 civilians have been killed in the country's north.\n\nWeary residents of Beirut on Thursday downplayed the chances of war in Lebanon, which a political deadlock has left essentially leaderless while a five-year economic meltdown continues.\n\nIn Israel, some citizens called for action against Hezbollah, and Noam Galili, 29, said: \"I know what it is like to live close to Lebanon, but it never felt as dangerous as it does now.\"\n\nThe violence has already displaced tens of thousands of people, mostly in Lebanon but also in northern Israel.\n\nIn southern Gaza, a United Nations mission found hundreds of thousands of displaced people \"suffer from poor access to shelter, health, food, water and sanitation,\" a UN report said late Wednesday.\n\nIn central Gaza, residents said they had turned to cooking oil to power their cars.\n\nUS President Joe Biden has called for the implementation of a ceasefire plan he outlined last month.\n\nHochstein and Washington's top diplomat, Blinken, say a deal to curb fighting in Gaza would by extension help resolve the Hezbollah-Israel violence.\n\nIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's far-right coalition partners strongly oppose a Gaza ceasefire.\n\nHe is also facing regular street protests by tens of thousands demanding a deal to free the hostages, and accusing him of prolonging the war.\n\n\"We will not leave the Gaza Strip until all of the hostages return,\" Netanyahu on Thursday told relatives of hostages killed in the territory.\n\n\"We do not have the option of giving up.\"\n\nIn a separate statement on Thursday he called the war a battle for Israel's existence.\n\n\"I am prepared to suffer personal attacks provided that Israel receives the ammunition from the US that it needs in the war for its existence,\" he said.\n\nHis statement came after he angered Washington with a video statement accusing it of \"withholding weapons and ammunitions to Israel\".\n\nThe White House on Thursday called Netanyahu's video statement \"vexing\".\n\nIsraeli military spokesman Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari told Israel's Channel 13 on Wednesday: \"To say that we are going to make Hamas disappear is to throw sand in people's eyes. If we don't provide an alternative, in the end, we will have Hamas.\"\n\nUS Secretary of State Antony Blinken last month said Washington had not seen an Israeli post-war plan and \"the trajectory Israel is on\" would still leave thousands of Hamas fighters.\n\nIsraeli government spokesman David Mencer said Thursday that Hamas's \"final stronghold\" in Rafah on the border with Egypt is
